revision.text:
'''AMD Lance Am7990''' [[IEEE 802.3]]<ref name="amd-17881-Am7990">{{cite web|title=AMD Am79C90 CMOS Local Area Network Controller for Ethernet (C-LANCE) |url=https://www.amd.com/files/connectivitysolutions/networking/archivednetworking/17881.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207052620/http://www.amd.com/files/connectivitysolutions/networking/archivednetworking/17881.pdf |archivedate=2008-12-07 }} 090427 amd.com</ref> Ethernet [[Media Access Control]]ler (MAC) controller were introduced in 1985.<ref name="amd_com_net186bd">{{cite web|title=Net186(tm) Demonstration Board User’s Manual|url=http://support.amd.com/it/Embedded_TechDocs/net186bd.pdf}} 090426 amd.com</ref> Its architecture is the basis for [[Advanced Micro Devices|AMD]]’s PCnet Family of highly integrated single-chip Ethernet controllers. The one exception is the Am79C940 MAC. The Am7990 chip was fabricated in [[nMOS logic|NMOS]] technology and has no integrated [[Manchester code|Manchester]] encoder/decoder (ENDEC) nor does it have an integrated [[10BASE-T]] transceiver.
[[File:AMD Am7990 die.JPG|thumb|AMD Am7990 LANCE die shot.]]
== Compatibility == {{original research|section|date=November 2010}} A later refabricated chip called the C-LANCE Am79C90 is made with 0.8 micrometre [[CMOS]] technology. The original NMOS version Am7990 and the CMOS Am79C90 version are differ in some details which may affect [[device driver]] compatibility.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}}
The datasheet for the CMOS version writes that the CMOS and NMOS versions are the same. But the "Table B-1. Comparison Summary of the C-LANCE and LANCE Devices" in the [[datasheet]] shows they differ. These differences are not likely to require modifications of any device driver.<!-- dault?, check datasheet! -->
The PCnet family of Ethernet controllers (PCnet-[[Industry Standard Architecture|ISA]] II, PCnet-32, PCnet-[[Conventional PCI|PCI]] II and PCnet-FAST) is LANCE software compatible. This means you should be able use the original 16-bit software on these members of the PCnet family of single-chip Ethernet controllers.
== Features == The Am7990 can handle [[10BASE-5]] Type A, [[10BASE-2]] Type B, and 10BASE-T. Back-to-back packet reception with as little as 0,5 µs interframe spacing. [[Direct memory access|DMA]]/[[Bus mastering]] 24-bit (16M) address capable. Up to 128 ring buffers can be used.<!-- "Up to 128 tasks may be queued up on a descriptor ring awaiting execution by the C-LANCE." --> 48 byte receive/transmit FIFO<!--CMOS has 48tx, 64rx FIFO-->. Operates with {{nowrap|5 volt DC 5%}} supply and logic. Features a [[Time-domain reflectometer]] (TDR) with a granularity of 30 meter<!-- light speed/10 MHz page 35 -->. {{nowrap|16,8 MHz}} maximum frequency.<!-- 6 * tTCT * 99ns page 38 in datasheet --> <ref name="amd-17881-Am7990" /> <!-- Free chip picture anyone? :-) -->
Physically a [[Dual in-line package|DIP-48]] or [[Plastic leaded chip carrier|PLCC-68]] package is used.<!-- if you need to physically locate the chip on a board --> CSR0 slave read data can cause timing violations on DAL lines.
== Chip bugs == The old LANCE (Rev. C) chips have a bug which causes garbage to be inserted in front of the received packet. The workaround is to ignore packets with an invalid destination address (garbage will usually not match). Of course, this precludes [[multicast]] support.<ref name="fxr_watson_org_am7990">{{cite web|title=fxr.watson.org: sys/dev/le/am7990.c|url=http://fxr.watson.org/fxr/source/dev/le/am7990.c}} 090426 fxr.watson.org</ref> The [[Amiga]] SANA-II network interface API has poor multicast support. And this chip bug might be the reason.
No capability for transmit buffer byte count of zero. Receive lockup may occur if bus latency is large. External loopback on a live network may cause reception of invalid loopback failure indications. Receive descriptor zero byte count buffer interpreted as 4096 available bytes. Will [[Polling (computer science)|poll]] computer memory every 1.6 [[Millisecond|ms]] for new packets to transmit.<!-- page 30 datasheet -->
== Uses == [[File:Am7990DC.jpg|thumb|AMD Am7990DC from SGI IP6 motherboard.]] * Amiga 2065 the first Ethernet controller for Amiga computer family. Uses the [[Amiga Zorro II|Zorro-II]] bus interface and equipped with the NMOS Am7990 chip.<ref name="amiga-hardware_com_905">{{cite web|title=Commodore: A2065 |url=http://www.amiga-hardware.com/showhardware.cgi?HARDID=905 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120150722/http://www.amiga-hardware.com/showhardware.cgi?HARDID=905 |archivedate=2013-01-20 }} 090426 amiga-hardware.com</ref><ref name="cvs_osdn_jp-a2065h">{{cite web|title=Amiga Linux/68k A2065 Ethernet Driver a2065.h|url=http://cvs.osdn.jp/cgi-bin/viewcvs.cgi/uclinux-h8/uClinux-2.0.x/drivers/net/a2065.h?view=co}} 090427 cvs.osdn.jp</ref> * [[MicroVAX]] [[Q-Bus]] Ethernet controllers (like the DELQA). * [[DECstation#Ethernet and SCSI|DECstation 2100/3100]] [[MIPS architecture]] [[motherboard]] Ethernet. * [[DEC 3000 AXP]] 64-bit [[Alpha AXP]] architecture motherboard. * SGI [[SGI IRIS 4D|Personal Iris]] MIPS [[R3000]] IP6 motherboard. * [[Sun Microsystems]] [[Sun-3#Sun-3x|Sun Hydra 3/80]],<ref name="net-kitchen_com_vol10">{{cite web|title=Suns-at-Home Digest V10 #2 |url=http://www.net-kitchen.com/~sah/ARCHIVES/DIGESTS/vol10.issue02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714163917/http://www.net-kitchen.com/~sah/ARCHIVES/DIGESTS/vol10.issue02 |archivedate=2011-07-14 }} 090427 net-kitchen.com</ref> [[SPARCstation 1]]<!-- Asfair! -->, [[SPARCstation 2]],<ref name="groups_google_com_5056f52275007c92">{{cite web|title=comp.unix.admin, How to know Sun CPU type, 1993|url=https://groups.google.com/group/comp.unix.admin/tree/browse_frm/month/1993-05/5056f52275007c92?rnum=121&_done=%2Fgroup%2Fcomp.unix.admin%2Fbrowse_frm%2Fmonth%2F1993-05%3F}} 090427 groups.google.com</ref> and [[SPARCstation#.22Lunchbox.22 systems|SPARCstation IPX]]<ref name="sunmanagers_org_0025">{{cite web|title=1993: SUMMARY min info script |url=http://www.sunmanagers.org/archives/1993/0025.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726145625/http://www.sunmanagers.org/archives/1993/0025.html |archivedate=2011-07-26 }} 090427 sunmanagers.org</ref> computer motherboard. * Various [[x86]]-[[Personal computer]] [[Industry Standard Architecture|ISA]] [[Network card|network interface cards]] (some called NE1500 and NE2100 <ref name="linhow5">{{cite web|title=Linux Ethernet-Howto: Vendor/Manufacturer/Model Specific Information|url=http://mm.iit.uni-miskolc.hu/data/texts/Linux/HOWTO/Ethernet-HOWTO-5.html}} 090428 mm.iit.uni-miskolc.hu</ref>). Under [[Unix]] [[operating system]]s like [[FreeBSD]]/[[NetBSD]]/[[OpenBSD]]/Linux the [[device driver]] is usually called le(4).<ref name="freebsd_le_4_71R">{{cite web|title=FreeBSD 7.1R manpage le(4)|url=http://www.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?query=le&apropos=0&sektion=4&manpath=FreeBSD+7.1-RELEASE&format=html}} 090426 freebsd.org</ref> * [[QEMU]] emulating [[Sun-4]] architecture (sun4m) virtual network interface. * [[GXemul]] with le(4) emulating [[ARM architecture|ARM]], [[MIPS architecture|MIPS]], [[Motorola 88000|M88K]], [[PowerPC]], and [[SuperH]] CPU. One example architecture is [[DECstation#Personal DECstation 5000 Series|DECstation 5000]] (3max).
== See also == * [[Ethernet]] * [[NE2000]] - 1987, Novell's NE2000 network card * [[3Com 3c509]] - 1994, 3Com 3c509 network card * [[RTL8139]] - 1999, Realtek 8139 PCI network chip
== References == <references />

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2015}} ''For the company of the same name that was founded in 1901 and renamed as the Gillette Safety Razor Company, see [[Gillette (brand)]]'' {{Infobox company | name = American Safety Razor Company | logo = | parent = [[Edgewell Personal Care]] | foundation = 1906 (as the Personna American Safety Razor Company) | location = [[Verona, Virginia]], US | industry = [[Personal care]] | products = [[Razor]], [[Shave brush]] | homepage = [http://www.personna.com/ Personna] }}
'''American Safety Razor Company''' is a personal care brand founded in the early 20th century (1906) by a merging of the Gem Cutlery Company & Ever-Ready and has been a principal competitor to [[Gillette (brand)|Gillette]] for a century and more. Unrelated to the Gillette company which also used the name '' 'American Safety Razor Company' '' in 1901 until 1904 before it was renamed for its founder, [[King C. Gillette]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=McDonough |first1=John |last2=Egolf |first2=Karen |title=The Advertising Age Encyclopedia of Advertising |date=2015 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=9781135949068 |page=673 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HZLtCQAAQBAJ}}</ref>
The company produces a wide range of personal care, medical, industrial blades and cutting tools with international operations in Canada, England, Mexico, Puerto Rico, and Israel.<ref>{{cite book|title=The National JobBank|publisher=Adams Media|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FlzHRE-WBAsC&pg=PT3439&dq=&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAjgUahUKEwizj-mP1_nIAhXErD4KHQW3Au0#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Crowd at Ebbets Field.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Gem Safety Razor advertised at the [[1920 World Series]] at [[Ebbets Field]].]]
===Star Safety Razor=== Frederick and Otto Kampfe were immigrants from [[Saxony]], Germany. In 1875 they applied for a U.S. patent and introduced the Star Razor, the first safety razor made in the United States. The brothers continued to improve their design and sold their products under the Star Safety Razor name in [[Brooklyn]], New York.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Williams|first1=David|title=The Iron Age|date=November 18, 1915|page=1211|edition=Volume 96, Issues 15–23|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jpUvAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA1211&dq=Kampfe+brothers&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDgQ6AEwBGoVChMI1ty4vd_5yAIVymw-Ch1Qywcs#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
===Gem Cutlery Company=== Jerry Reichard, after working for the Kampfe Brothers for 23 years, leaves to start his own company – the Gem Cutlery Company in 1898.<ref>{{cite web |title=American Safety Razor Company: A Name To Reckon With |url=https://malegroomings.com/American-Safety-Razor-Company |website=malegroomings.com |accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=The source mentions Wikipedia as a source for some of its information|date=November 2018}} Its first product, the Gem Safety Razor, borrowed heavily from the Star Razor in design but soon outpaces the Star in sales.<ref>{{cite web|title=Personna History|url=http://www.personna.com/about-us/history|website=personna.com}}</ref>
===Ever-Ready=== In 1903 Jerry Reichard leaves Gem Safety Razor Company to form yet another razor and blade producer, along with August Scheuber the company was briefly named 'Reichard & Scheuber Manufacturing Company'<ref>{{cite web|title=US Patent 769114|url=https://razors.click/patents/US769114/|website=razors.click}}</ref> before it became 'The Yankee Company'. The Yankee Company made wedge-blade razors under the name Yankee, Mohican & Winner. The Yankee Company, is renamed Ever-Ready in 1905. Gem & Ever-Ready merge in 1906 and is incorporated as the Personna American Safety Razor Company. In 1906, abandoning the wedge-blade design, they introduced the standard single edge rib-back blade that is still used today.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Waits|first1=Robert K.|title=A Safety Razor Compendium|date=November 17, 2014|page=389|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4oX3BgAAQBAJ&pg=PA389&dq=&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAGoVChMI58f96d74yAIVgTwmCh3IaQcj#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> In 1915 Ever-Ready Shaving Brushes were first introduced and continued to be produced until the early 1990s.
===Safetee Soap Corporation=== In December 1919 The Safetee Soap Corporation formed as a subsidiary of American Safety Razor Corporation and produced a line of shaving soaps, creams, powders, talc and aftershave lotions to compliment the safety razor business.<ref>{{cite book|title=Printers' Ink|date=March 17, 1921|pages=20|edition=Volume 114|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=STwyAQAAMAAJ&pg=RA10-PA20&dq#v=onepage&q&f=true}}</ref> The Safetee Soap line was [[cross-promotion|cross-promoted]] in pamphlets included in other ASR products.<ref>{{cite book|title=How Safetee Soap Creates New Sales|date=January 1921|publisher=The American Cutler|pages=7–8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KiodAQAAMAAJ&pg=PP11&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=true}}</ref>
===American Safety Razor Corporation=== Gem & Ever-Ready merged with Star to become the American Safety Razor Corporation in 1919. It was chartered in Virginia, while razor and blade production remained in Brooklyn. By 1921, it had produced 1,800,000 safety razors; 110,000,000 razor blades; 1,000,000 shaving brushes; 2,000,000 cakes of shaving soap.<ref>{{cite book|title=Moodys Manual of Railroads and Corporation Securities|date=1922|publisher=Moody Manual Company|edition=Volume 1; Volume 2, Part 1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xdk5AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA1232&dq=&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDwQ6AEwAmoVChMI58f96d74yAIVgTwmCh3IaQcj#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> By 1942, it had introduced and popularized the phrase ''[[five o'clock shadow]]''. In 1953, it acquired the Pal, Treet and Personna brands after purchasing the Pal Blade Company. These two product names continue to be made today. In 1954 the factory relocated to [[Staunton, Virginia]], after the Brooklyn City Planning Commission's planned civic center encroached on the factory with plans to redevelop the industrial area into office and residential use.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Freeman|first1=Joshua Benjamin|title=Working-Class New York: Life and Labor Since World War II|date=2001|publisher=The New Press|page=147|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zmwRBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA147&dq=&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDQQ6AEwATgKahUKEwji76D55_jIAhXDOD4KHeZYCek#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> The American Safety Razor factory building at 333 Jay Street then became the new campus for the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn.
Seeking diversification [[Altria|Philip Morris]] acquires American Safety Razor in 1960. In 1963 American Safety Razor is the first maker of stainless steel blades, which were sold under the Personna brand name. In 1968, Philip Morris, purchased the Burma-Vita Company, makers of [[Burma-Shave]]. In 1970, the first blade made with tungsten steel was introduced, the Personna 74. In 1974 American Line Brand of industrial products was introduced, expanding the company into industrial blades. In 1977, executives purchased Personna American Safety Razor Company from Philip Morris in a management buyout.
[[Energizer]] bought the privately held American Safety Razor in 2011, when it filed for bankruptcy.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Peters|first1=Laura|title=Verona Energizer plant may shut down|url=http://www.newsleader.com/story/news/local/2015/06/04/veronas-energizer-plant-could-face--shutdown/28469203/|website=newsleader.com}}</ref> In 2015, Energizer spun off the personal care division as Edgewell Personal Care.<ref>{{cite web|title=Edgewell History|url=http://edgewell.com/our-history/|website=edgewell.com}}</ref> Edgewell announced the sale of its Personna Industrial Division to an investment group, which renamed it AccuTec Blades.<ref>{{cite web|title=Investment group purchases Personna Industrial Division|url=http://augustafreepress.com/investment-group-purchases-personna-industrial-division-verona-plant-to-remain-operational-continue-to-provide-150-jobs/|website=augustafreepress.com}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1906]] [[Category:Companies based in Virginia]] [[Category:Personal care brands]] [[Category:1906 establishments in New York (state)]]

'''Anal bleaching''' is the process of [[skin whitening|lightening the color of the skin]] around the [[anus]]. It is done for cosmetic purposes, to make the color of the anus more uniform with the surrounding area. Some treatments are applied in an office or salon by a cosmetic technician and others are sold as cream that can be applied at home.
==History== [[pornographic film actor|Pornography actresses]] were the first to undergo the anal bleaching process, in an effort to lighten the color of their anuses to match the rest of their skin,<ref name=cosbut>{{cite web |url=http://www.cosmopolitan.com/health-fitness/advice/a3634/anal-bleaching-trend/ |title=The Scary New Butt Beauty Trend |work=[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]] |date=3 August 2011}}</ref> although it has been suggested by Kristina Rose that this is not the case.<ref name=lawana>{{cite web |url=http://www.laweekly.com/columns/anal-bleaching-from-porn-trend-to-mainstream-un-necessary-evil-2529810 |title=Anal Bleaching: From Porn Trend to Mainstream (Un)Necessary Evil |work=[[LA Weekly]] |date=8 February 2012}}</ref> As [[Brazilian waxing]] became popular, due to the popularity of smaller swimsuits and lingerie, the spread of pornography into the mainstream, and endorsement of the procedure by celebrities,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2011/12/the-new-full-frontal-has-pubic-hair-in-america-gone-extinct/249798/ |title=The New Full-Frontal: Has Pubic Hair in America Gone Extinct? |work=[[The Atlantic]] |date=13 December 2011}}</ref> women began noticing that their anuses were darker than the rest of their skin.<ref name=cosbut /> The increase in the number of women engaging in anal sex has also contributed to women's concern over the appearance of their anus.<ref name=cosbut /> To combat this perceived problem, genital bleaching began to gain appeal.<ref name=lawana /> Gay men also make use of this procedure.<ref name=marana /><ref name=tvvbun />
The procedure was briefly shown in 2004 near the end of an episode ''[[Cosmetic Surgery Live]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2004/sep/19/features.review57 |title=Why actions speak louder |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=19 September 2004}}</ref> One salon that performed the procedure received an increase in queries in 2005 attributed to an episode of ''[[Dr. 90210]]'' on [[E!]], when porn star [[Tabitha Stevens]] was filmed having her anus bleached.<ref name=tvvbun>{{cite web |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2005-07-05/columns/britesmile-for-bungholes/ |title=Britesmile for Bungholes |work=[[The Village Voice]] |date=5 July 2005}}</ref> It garnered several mentions in movies such as ''[[Brüno]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tmz.com/2009/05/12/bruno-sacha-baron-cohen-anus-bleach/#.T5G_29XcyqI |title=Bruno on Anus: I'm Bleached and I'm Proud! |work=[[TMZ]] |date=15 December 2009}}</ref> and ''[[Bridesmaids (2011 film)|Bridesmaids]]'',<ref name=cosbut /> and in magazines.<ref name=cosbut /><ref name=marana>{{cite web |url=http://www.marieclaire.com/sex-love/advice/a712/anal-bleaching/ |title=Is Anal Bleaching for You? |work=[[Marie Claire]] |date=21 July 2011}}</ref>
The treatment was apparently first offered in the US in California in 2005; it was reported to be available at the same time in Australia.<ref name=tvvbun /> Spas outside of Hollywood were slow to begin offering it as a beauty treatment, with just one New York spa offering the service by 2007.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timeout.com/newyork/things-to-do/ass-you-like-it |title=Ass you like it |work=[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out New York]] |date=11 October 2007}}</ref> Creams are now sold for use at home,<ref name=nexwhi>{{cite web |url=http://www.nextmagazine.com/content/once-you-go-white |title=Once You Go White |work=[[Next Magazine (New York City)|Next Magazine]] |date=18 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150123161258/http://www.nextmagazine.com/content/once-you-go-white |archivedate=23 January 2015 |df= }}</ref> and genital lightening is offered as a laser-based treatment in cosmetic surgery centers.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}}<!--I could link to a number of websites to support this, but I'm having trouble finding one that isn't a promotional primary source--> Although the popularity of anal bleaching has not approached that of Brazilian waxing, it has garnered mainstream recognition over the past several years.<ref name=lawana />
==Methods== There are several methods to carry out the anal lightening process. The most common method is to simply use an at-home lotion or gel to target the darkened anal and genital area and gradually fade the darkened area over time. Most of the other methods that are used for skin lightening, like [[Hydroquinone#Skin depigmentation|hydroquinone]] used to lighten skin and usually found in products marketed to darker skinned people to even out their skin tone,<ref name=tvvbun /> and other popular methods like [[cryosurgery]] and laser lightening treatments, are also used for anal bleaching.{{Citation needed|date=December 2014}}
==Risks== Many of these [[cosmetics]] contained ingredients that would irritate the sensitive anal area, creating temporary discomfort and even burning, scarring, or [[Fecal incontinence|incontinence]].<ref name=nexwhi />
The process performed with creams containing [[Hydroquinone#Skin depigmentation|hydroquinone]] is banned in some countries, such as the member states of the EU.<ref name=ctpa>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefactsabout.org.uk/content.asp?menuid=32&submenuid=136&pageid=136&menuname=Skin+lightening+products&menu=sub |title=Skincare: Skin lightening products |work=Cosmetic, Toiletry and Perfumery Association |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150123180529/http://www.thefactsabout.org.uk/content.asp?menuid=32&submenuid=136&pageid=136&menuname=Skin+lightening+products&menu=sub |archivedate=2015-01-23 |df= }}</ref> In 2006, the [[FDA]] removed previous advice that stated hydroquinone was considered generally safe, as hydroquinone has been linked to [[ochronosis]], where skin becomes permanently discoloured and disfigured, and because it may also be a [[carcinogen]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fda.gov/AboutFDA/CentersOffices/OfficeofMedicalProductsandTobacco/CDER/ucm203112.htm |title=Hydroquinone Studies Under The National Toxicology Program (NTP) |work=[[Food and Drug Administration]]}}</ref> However, its use is not banned in the [[United States]] and it is still in use.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://safecosmetics.org/article.php?id=289 |title=Hydroquinone |work=[[Campaign for Safe Cosmetics]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150123171201/http://safecosmetics.org/article.php?id=289 |archivedate=2015-01-23 |df= }}</ref>
Other principal ingredients that are used in skin lightening cosmetics are [[arbutin]] and [[kojic acid]].<ref name=ctpa/> Arbutin, often also called ''bearberry'', can be converted by the body into hydroquinone.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ntp.niehs.nih.gov/ntp/htdocs/chem_background/exsumpdf/arbutin_508.pdf#search=Arbutin%20%20hydroquinone |title=Chemical Information Review Document for Arbutin [CAS No. 497-76-7] and Extracts from Arctostaphylos uva-ursi |work=[[National Toxicology Program]] |date=January 2006}}</ref> [[Azelaic acid]] with products like [[aloe vera]] and [[vitamin C]] tablets is another method.{{Citation needed|date=December 2015}} [[Kojic acid]] was developed as a safer alternative to hydroquinone, however it is less effective at lightening and also [[carcinogenic]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.health24.com/Sex/Sexual-diversity/Backdoor-bleaching-20120721 |title=Backdoor bleaching |work=[[News24]] |date=24 February 2009}}</ref>
Laser-based and [[cryogenic]] anal or genital lightening does come with its own set of warnings. Results are not always consistent, the process may be a painful one, and those with darker skin tones may have issues with these processes {{Clarify|date=December 2014}}. Lasers also have the added disadvantage of leaving scars, so cryogenic skin lightening is the option usually used for the anal and genital area.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}}
==See also== * [[Labiaplasty]] * [[Vajazzle]]

{{Infobox company | name = AnswerDash | logo = AnswerDash logo.png | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_padding = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | former_name = Qazzow<ref name="GW14"/> | trading_name = | type = | traded_as = | ISIN = | industry = [[Computer software]], [[Internet]] | genre = | fate = | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = 2012<!-- if known: {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} in [[city]], [[state]], [[country]] --> | founders = [[Jacob O. Wobbrock]], Andy Ko, Parmit Chilana<ref name="PSBJ35-48"/> | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location = 1501 4th Avenue | hq_location_city = [[Seattle, Washington]] | hq_location_country = [[United States]] | num_locations = | num_locations_year = <!-- Year of num_locations data (if known) --> | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = Bill Colleran, President & CEO | products = | brands = | production = | production_year = <!-- Year of production data (if known) --> | services = | revenue = | revenue_year = <!-- Year of revenue data (if known) --> | operating_income = | income_year = <!-- Year of operating_income data (if known) --> | net_income = <!-- or: | profit = --> | net_income_year = <!-- or: | profit_year = --><!-- Year of net_income/profit data (if known) --> | aum = <!-- Only for financial-service companies --> | assets = | assets_year = <!-- Year of assets data (if known) --> | equity = $2.54 million<ref name="PSBJ35-48"/> | equity_year = 2015 | owner = | members = | members_year = <!-- Year of members data (if known) --> | num_employees = 12<ref name="PSBJ35-48"/> | num_employees_year = 2015 | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | slogan = <!-- or: | slogans = --> | module = <!-- Used to embed other templates --> | ratio = <!-- Basel III ratio, for BANKS ONLY --> | rating = <!-- credit rating, for BANKS ONLY --> | website = {{URL|answerdash.com}} | footnotes = }} {{Coord|47|36|36.43|N|122|20|15.21|W|display=title}} '''AnswerDash''' is a [[Business-to-business|B2B]] [[software company]] that facilitates [[customer service]] for [[e-commerce]] businesses. AnswerDash was founded in [[Seattle, Washington]] in 2012 as a [[university spin-off|spin-off]] from the [[Information school]] of the [[University of Washington]].<ref name="BL"/> Its [[software-as-a-service]] utilizes [[machine learning]] to create databases of [[Context-sensitive help|context-sensitive support answers]] for [[end-user]]s of [[webpage]]s and [[mobile application]]s, thus reducing the need for human customer service.<ref name="PSBJ35-48"/> AnswerDash claims to be the first,<ref name="GW13a"/> and as of 2015 the world's leading provider of contextual point-and-click answer technology.<ref name="YF15"/>
== History == [[File:Qazzow_logo_(former_logo_of_AnswerDash).png|200px|thumb|left|The former logo of AnswerDash]] The company was founded under name ″Qazzow″ in 2012 by three [[University of Washington]] employees:<ref name="BL"/> [[Jacob O. Wobbrock]], a [[professor]] and the director of Mobile & Accessible Design Lab,<ref name="uwj"/> Andy Ko, an associate professor the director of Code & Cognition Lab,<ref name="uwa"/> and Parmit Chilana, a [[research assistant]] and a [[graduate student]] at the time, now a professor at [[Simon Fraser University]].<ref name="vb"/> Jake Wobbrock assumed the responsibilities of [[CEO]], and Andy Ko became the company's [[Chief technology officer|CTO]].<ref name="sed"/> The idea of the key company's service stemmed from Parmit Chilana's [[dissertation]] on [[human–computer interaction]].<ref name="ST"/> Her research has highlighted a very high proportion (up to 95%) of users' questions that are triggered by something seen on a website and should benefit from contextual help.<ref name="vb"/>
In November 2013 the company received $500,000 seed investment from [[W Fund]] to further develop its contextual Q&A service<ref name="GW13a"/><ref name="uwn"/> and in December 2013 additional $2.4 million from [[WRF Capital]] and [[Voyager Capital]] investment funds.<ref name="GW13b"/> In May 2014, the company re-branded itself to ″AnswerDash″ reacting to customers' confusion over the unusual sequence of letters in the original name.<ref name="GW14"/><ref name="BL"/>
In January 2015, Kevin Knoepp has replaced Andy Ko as AnswerDash new CTO.<ref name="YF15a"/> AnswerDash service came on-line in May 2015.<ref name="SEA15"/> At the same time, after serving as a CEO for three years, Jake Wobbrock stepped down as the CEO. His performance was generally favored by [[Board of directors|the board]], but Wobbrok has admitted his tendency to focusing on interesting scientific details that might not be relevant to business success.<ref name="NYT"/> Wobbrock was replaced by William Colleran, a former CEO [[Impinj]].<ref name="YF16"/>
By the end of 2015 the company has "matured dramatically".<ref name="GW15"/> After announcing the successful deployment of its software to [[Zendesk]],<ref name="xc"/> in September AnswerDash raised additional $2.9 million.<ref name="GW15"/> In 2016, AnswerDash has recorded the biggest jump in [[GeekWire]] 200 rating, a ranked index of [[Pacific Northwest]] [[Startup company|startups]].<ref name="GW16"/>
== Services == Offered under [[SaaS]] model by subscription, the service aims to eliminate the need for separate FAQs or ″help islands" offering contextual answers to end-users' questions.<ref name="CIO"/> The service can be used on [[website]]s, [[web application]]s, and [[mobile application]]s. It employs a [[Natural language processing|natural-language engine]] and [[machine learning]] technology that allows website and application owners to build the database of answers in a matter of several days.<ref name="vb"/>
In addition, AnswerDash utilizes [[data mining]] technology to provide business owners with valuable analytics on their consumers' behavior that leads to further improvement of their e-commerce services.<ref name="sbt"/><ref name="PDSSE"/> AnswerDash claims to reduce the need of traditional [[customer support]] by 30 to 50 percent.<ref name="YF16"/>

[[File:Taichung Thermal Power Plant.JPG|thumb|A coal power station in [[Taiwan]].]] The '''baseload'''<ref name="baseload">{{Cite web|url=https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/baseload|title=Definition of "baseload"|last=|first=|date=|website=www.merriam-webster.com|publisher=Merriam Webster Dictionary|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-12-02}}</ref> (also '''base load''') on a grid is the minimum level of demand on an [[electrical grid]] over a span of time, for example, one week. This demand can be met by unvarying power plants,<ref name="fink78" /> [[dispatchable generation]],<ref name="pembina"/> or by a collection of smaller [[intermittent energy source]]s,<ref name="stanford" /> depending on which approach has the best mix of low cost, availability and high reliability in any particular market. The remainder of demand, varying throughout a day, is met by dispatchable generation, [[load following power plant]]s, and [[peaking power plant]]s, which can be turned up or down quickly, [[operating reserve]], [[demand response]] and [[energy storage]].
When the cheapest power was from large coal and nuclear plants which could not be turned up or down quickly, they were used to generate baseload, since it is constant, and they were called "baseload plants." Large standby reserves were needed in case of sudden failure of one of these large plants.<ref name="fink78"> Donald G. Fink, H. Wayne Beatty (ed), ''Standard Handbook for Electrical Engineers'', Eleventh Edition, Mc-Graw Hill, 1978 {{ISBN|9780070209749}}, pp. 12-16 through 12-18 </ref><ref name="vortex">{{cite web |url= http://www.energyvortex.com/energydictionary/baseload_plant.html |title=Energy Dictionary - Baseload plant |publisher=EnergyVortex.com |date= |accessdate=2008-08-03}}</ref> Unvarying power plants are no longer always the cheapest way to meet baseload. The grid now includes many wind turbines which have such low marginal costs that they can bid lower prices than coal or nuclear, so they can provide some of the baseload when the wind blows. Using wind turbines in areas with varying wind conditions, and supplementing them with solar in the day time, dispatchable generation and storage, handles the intermittency of individual wind sources.<ref name="pembina" /><ref name="stanford" />
==Description== [[Regional transmission organization (North America)|Grid operators]] take [[Electricity_market#Bid-based,_security-constrained,_economic_dispatch_with_nodal_prices|long and short term bids]] to provide electricity over various time periods and [[Grid balancing|balance supply and demand]] continuously.<ref name="ibrd">{{Cite book |url=http://www-wds.worldbank.org/external/default/WDSContentServer/WDSP/IB/2011/08/18/000356161_20110818032547/Rendered/PDF/638750PUB0Exto00Box0361531B0PUBLIC0.pdf |title=Electricity Auctions: An Overview of Efficient Practices |last=Maurer |first=Luiz T.A., Luiz A. Barroso |year=2011 |isbn=978-0-8213-8822-8}}</ref> The detailed adjustments are known as the [[unit commitment problem in electrical power production]].
While historically large power grids used unvarying power plants to meet the base load, there is no specific technical requirement for this to be so. The base load can equally well be met by the appropriate quantity of [[intermittent power source]]s and [[dispatchable generation]].<ref name="pembina">{{Cite web |url=http://pubs.pembina.org/reports/TheBasicsOnBaseload.pdf |title=The Basics on Base Load: Meeting Ontario’s Base Load Electricity Demand with Renewable Power Sources |last=Peters |first=Roger, Cherise Burda |date=2007-09-01 |website=Pembina Institute |access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref><ref name="stanford">{{Cite journal |last=Archer |first=Cristina L. |last2=Jacobson |first2=Mark Z. |date=November 2007 |title=Supplying Baseload Power and Reducing Transmission Requirements by Interconnecting Wind Farms |url=http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/abs/10.1175/2007JAMC1538.1 |journal=Journal of Applied Meteorology and Climatology |language=EN |volume=46 |issue=11 |pages=1701–1717 |doi=10.1175/2007jamc1538.1 |issn=1558-8424}}</ref>
Unvarying power plants can be coal, nuclear, [[combined cycle]] plants, which may take several days to start up and shut down,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/why-baseload-power-is-doomed/|title=Why baseload power is doomed {{!}} ZDNet|last=Nelder|first=Chris|work=ZDNet|access-date=2018-12-02|language=en}}</ref> [[Hydroelectricity|hydroelectric]], [[Geothermal power|geothermal]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/articles/2007/10/scaling-geothermal-for-reliable-baseload-power-50159.html |title=Scaling Geothermal for Reliable Baseload Power|publisher=renewableenergyworld.com |date=2007-10-05 |accessdate=2008-08-03}}</ref> [[biogas]], [[biomass]], [[Solar_thermal#Heat_storage|solar thermal with storage]] and [[ocean thermal energy conversion]].
Supply interruptions can affect all plants from breakdowns, and also hydroelectric plants from [[drought]]s, coal plants if their coal stockpiles freeze, and gas plants from pipeline leaks and closures.
The desirable attribute of [[Dispatchable generation|dispatchability]] applies to some gas plants, wind (through [[Blade_pitch#Wind_turbines|blade pitch]]) and hydroelectricity. Grid operators also use ''curtailment'' to shut plants out of the grid when their energy is not needed.<ref name="curt1">{{Cite journal |last=Bird |first=Lori |last2=Lew |first2=Debra |last3=Milligan |first3=Michael |last4=Carlini |first4=E. Maria |last5=Estanqueiro |first5=Ana |last6=Flynn |first6=Damian |last7=Gomez-Lazaro |first7=Emilio |last8=Holttinen |first8=Hannele |last9=Menemenlis |first9=Nickie |date=November 2016 |title=Wind and solar energy curtailment: A review of international experience |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1364032116303161 |journal=Renewable and Sustainable Energy Reviews |volume=65 |pages=577–586 |doi=10.1016/j.rser.2016.06.082 |issn=1364-0321}}</ref><ref name="curt2">{{Cite web |url=https://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/renewables-curtailment-in-california-and-the-midwest-what-can-we-learn-from#gs.93GvC=4 |title=Renewables Curtailment: What We Can Learn From Grid Operations in California and the Midwest |last=GIMON |first=ERIC, ROBBIE ORVIS AND SONIA AGGARWAL |date=2015-03-23 |website=Green Tech Media |access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref>
There are 195,000 megawatts of grid storage installed world-wide; 94% is [[pumped-storage hydroelectricity]]; 2% is in batteries.<ref name="storage">{{Cite web |url=http://www.energystorageexchange.org/projects |title=DOE Global Energy Storage Database |website=www.energystorageexchange.org |access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref> Pumped storage uses cheap power at times of low demand, usually night, to pump water from a lower reservoir to an upper reservoir, then lets it drop back through turbines during peak demand times, usually in the day. Availability of solar power in peak hours of the day can reduce the need for storage. The [[Bath County Pumped Storage Station|biggest storage facility]] in the world is on the Virginia-West Virginia border, with 50% more capacity than the [[Hoover Dam]].<ref name="ryan">{{Cite news |url=http://thinkprogress.org/the-inside-story-of-the-worlds-biggest-battery-and-the-future-of-renewable-energy-8984e81283c/ |title=The Inside Story Of The World’s Biggest ‘Battery’ And The Future Of Renewable Energy |last=KORONOWSKI |first=Ryan |date=2013-08-27 |work=ThinkProgress |access-date=2018-05-16 |language=en-US}}</ref>
== Economics ==
Grid operators solicit bids to find the cheapest sources of electricity over short and long term buying periods.<ref name="alj">{{Cite news |url=http://america.aljazeera.com/opinions/2014/5/electricity-auctionpricespowerbillsconsumers.html |title=OPINION: How electricity auctions are rigged to favor industry |last=Johnston |first=David Cay |date=2014-05-29 |work=Al Jazeera |access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref>
Nuclear and coal plants have very high [[fixed costs]], high [[plant load factor]] but very low [[marginal costs]], though not as low as solar, wind, and hydroelectric. On the other hand, peak load generators, such as [[natural gas]], have low fixed costs, low plant load factor and high marginal costs.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aF7lWf14H2EC&pg=PA77&lpg=PA77&dq=hydro+base+load&source=web&ots=qAfGeztoow&sig=9ZbHwDwDOUmzcBhXyZdmp7SU3bw&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result |title=Ontario Hydro at the Millennium: Has Monopoly's Moment Passed? |author=Ronald J. Daniels |publisher=Montreal and Kingston: McGill-Queen's University Press |year=1996 |accessdate=2008-08-03}}</ref>
Coal and nuclear power plants do not change production to match power consumption demands since it is more economical to operate them at constant production levels. Use of higher cost combined-cycle plants or combustion turbines is thus minimized, and these plants can be cycled up and down to match more rapid fluctuations in consumption. Some nuclear power stations, such as those [[nuclear power in France|in France]], do operate as [[load following power plant]]s and alter their output to meet varying demands.<ref>Nuclear Development, June 2011, page 10 from http://www.oecd-nea.org/</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd-nea.org/|title=Nuclear Development|last=|first=|date=|website=www.oecd-nea.org|publisher=Nuclear Energy Agency|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-12-02}}</ref>
Different plants and technologies may have differing capacities to increase or decrease output on demand: nuclear plants are generally run at close to maximum output continuously (apart from maintenance, [[Nuclear fuel|refueling]] and periodic refurbishment), while coal-fired plants may be cycled over the course of a day to meet demand.{{Citation needed|date=June 2008}} Plants with multiple generating units may be used as a group to improve the "fit" with demand, by turning units on and off.
According to [[National Grid plc]] [[chief executive officer]] [[Steve Holliday]] in 2015, baseload is "outdated", as microgrids would become the primary means of production, and large powerplants relegated to supply the remainder.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.energypost.eu/interview-steve-holliday-ceo-national-grid-idea-large-power-stations-baseload-power-outdated/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160910134728/http://www.energypost.eu/interview-steve-holliday-ceo-national-grid-idea-large-power-stations-baseload-power-outdated/ |title=Steve Holliday CEO National Grid: baseload is outdated |date=11 September 2015 |archivedate=10 September 2016 |author=Karel Beckman |work=EnergyPost.eu |accessdate=6 October 2016 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
In 2016, [[Ambrose Evans-Pritchard]] of the [[Daily Telegraph]] wrote that, with advances in energy storage, 'there ceases to be much point in building costly "[[baseload]]" power plants' and goes on to argue 'Nuclear reactors cannot be switched on and off as need demands - unlike gas plants. They are useless as a back-up for the decentralized grid of the future, when wind, solar, hydro, and other renewables will dominate the power supply'.<ref>{{cite news| url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2016/08/10/holy-grail-of-energy-policy-in-sight-as-battery-technology-smash/ |title= Holy Grail of energy policy in sight as battery technology smashes the old order |first= Ambrose |last= Evans-Pritchard |newspaper= The Telegraph |date= 10 August 2016}}</ref>

The '''bomber gap''' was the [[Cold War]] belief that the [[Soviet Union]]'s [[Long Range Aviation]] department had gained an advantage in deploying [[jet aircraft|jet-powered]] [[strategic bomber]]s. Widely accepted for several years, the gap was used as a political [[talking point]] in the [[United States]] to justify a great increase in [[defense spending]].
One result was a massive buildup of the [[US Air Force]] bomber fleet, which peaked at over 2500 bombers to counter the perceived Soviet threat. Surveillance flights by the [[Lockheed U-2|U-2]] aircraft indicated that the bomber gap did not exist.
Realizing that the belief in the gap was an extremely effective funding source, the US military fabricated a series of similarly-nonexistent Soviet military advances. That tactic is now known as [[policy by press release]]. Some of the claims were a [[nuclear aircraft|nuclear-powered bomber]],<ref>''Soviets Flight Testing Nuclear Bomber'', Aviation Week, 1 December 1958, p. 27.</ref> [[Supersonic speed|supersonic]] [[VTOL]] [[Avro Canada VZ-9 Avrocar|flying saucers]],<ref>''Is this the real Flying Saucer?'', Look, Volume 19, 14 June 1955</ref> and, only a few years later, the [[missile gap]].
==Appearance == On February 15, 1954, ''[[Aviation Week]]'' published an article describing new Soviet jet bombers capable of carrying a [[nuclear bomb]] from their bases to the US.<ref>''Pictures Reveal Reds' New "Sunday Punch"'', Aviation Week, 15 Feb. 1954, 12–13</ref> The aircraft was the [[Myasishchev M-4]] ''Bison''. Over the next year and a half, the rumors were debated publicly in the press and soon in [[US Congress|Congress]].<ref>''Congress Gets Red Plane Facts'', Aviation Week, 22 February 1954, pp. 13–14</ref>
==Soviet Aviation Day deception== Adding to the concerns was an infamous event in July 1955. At the [[Soviet Aviation Day]] demonstrations at the [[Tushino Airfield]], ten Bison bombers were flown past the reviewing stand, flew out of sight, quickly turned around, and then flew past the stands again with eight more. That presented the illusion that there were 28 aircraft in the flyby. Western analysts, extrapolating from the illusionary 28 aircraft, judged that by 1960, the Soviets would have 800.<ref name="heppenheimer1998">{{cite book | title=The Space Shuttle Decision | publisher=NASA | author=Heppenheimer, T. A. | year=1998 | page=193 | url=https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4221/contents.htm}}</ref>
==US Air Force raises numbers of bombers== At the time, the Air Force had just introduced its own strategic jet bomber, the [[B-52 Stratofortress]], and the shorter-range [[B-47 Stratojet]] was still suffering from a variety of technical problems that limited its availability. Its staff started pressing for accelerated production of the B-52 but also grudgingly accepted calls for expanded air defense.<ref>[http://www.dean-boys.com/551aew/navy_air_defence.htm Guarding the Cold War Ramparts: The U.S. Navy's Role in Continental Air Defense]</ref>
The Air Force was generally critical of spending effort on defense after it had studied the results of the [[World War II]] bombing campaigns and concluded that British Prime Minister [[Stanley Baldwin]]'s pre-war thinking on the fruitlessness of air defense was mostly correct: "[[The bomber will always get through]]." Like the British, the US Air Force concluded that money would better be spent on making the offensive arm larger to deter an attack. The result was a production series consisting of thousands of aircraft. Over 2,000 B-47s and almost 750 B-52s were built to match the imagined fleet of Soviet aircraft.
==Disproval of gap== {{Disputed section|1956 overflight of Engels|date = February 2017}}
US President [[Dwight Eisenhower]] had always been skeptical of the gap. However, with no evidence to disprove it, he agreed to the development of the [[Lockheed U-2|U-2]] to find out for sure.<ref>[http://www.coldwar.org/articles/50s/bomber_gap.asp Bomber Gap]</ref>
The first U-2 flights started in 1956. One early mission, Mission 2020, flown by [[Martin Knutson]] on July 4, 1956,<ref>[http://www.spyflight.co.uk/u2.htm Lockheed U-2 mission history]</ref> flew over [[Engels-2]] airfield, near [[Saratov]], and photographed 20 [[M-4 Bison]] bombers on the ramp. Multiplying by the number of Soviet bomber bases, the intelligence suggested the Soviets were already well on their way to deploying hundreds of aircraft. The U-2 had actually photographed the entire Bison fleet; there was no bomber at any of the other bases.<ref>[http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/coldwar/interviews/episode-8/knutson2.html Interview with Martin Knutson]</ref> Similar missions over the next year finally proved that. At least in official circles, the gap had been disproved.{{r|heppenheimer1998}}
Other newly declassified information indicates that Engels was never overflown, and nothing was confirmed about Bison aircraft numbers until December 1959<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/readingroom/docs/CIA-RDP61S00750A000500040115-4.pdf (U) Heavy Bomber Targets], CIA-RDP61S00750A000500040115-4, Central Intelligence Agency, May 21, 1958.</ref><ref>[Mission 8005 Submitted 18 December 1959] (Document title of Mission 8035 is in error, see copy), CIA-RDP78B05700A000400200005-1, Central Intelligence Agency, December 21, 1959</ref><ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/readingroom/docs/CIA-RDP78T05693A000300050001-4.pdf ODE 8005], CIA-RDP78T05693A000300050001-4, Central Intelligence Agency, December 13, 1959.</ref> The downward revision in Bison numbers was caused by new information from the factories that was received in 1958. It showed that production rate had slowed down.<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/readingroom/docs/CIA-RDP61-00549R000200010002-1.pdf Validity of Hevy Bomber Estimate in NIE 11-4-57], CIA-RDP61-00549R000200010002-1, Central Intelligence Agency, April 11, 1958.</ref><ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/readingroom/docs/CIA-RDP79R00904A000400030035-9.pdf Recent Evidence on Bison Production] (Top Secret), CIA-RDP79R00904A000400030035-9, Central Intelligence Agency, July 9, 1958.</ref>
As it was later discovered, the M-4 was unable to meet its original range goals and was limited to about {{convert|8000|km|sp=us}}. Unlike the US, the Soviets still lacked overseas bases in the [[Western Hemisphere]] and so the M-4 could not attack the US and then land at a friendly airbase. Interest in the M-4 waned, and a total of only 93 were produced before the assembly lines were shut down in 1963.
The vast majority were used as tankers or maritime reconnaissance aircraft; only the original ten shown at the air show and nine newer 3MD13 models served on nuclear alert.<ref>[http://www.fas.org/nuke/guide/russia/bomber/m-4.htm Myasishchev 'Bison']</ref>
==In popular culture== *In [[Stanley Kubrick]]'s movie ''[[Dr. Strangelove]]'', the notion of a "bomber gap" is parodied when the character of Buck Turgidson (a Pentagon general) declares that the US "must not allow a mineshaft gap" in discussing the use of mineshafts as nuclear [[fallout shelters]]. *In one episode of U.S. television situation comedy ''[[That '70s Show]]'', "Who Wants It More", [[Donna Pinciotti|Donna]] and [[Eric Forman|Eric]] do a report in his bedroom for school on the arms race between the superpowers. After several "[[foreplay|study breaks]]" in which they [[make out]], the two disagree over the "bomber gap." Donna incorrectly suggests that the Soviets started the arms race with the bomber gap; after Eric corrects her, she refuses further "study breaks."
==See also== * [[Missile gap]] * [[Nuclear arms race]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Cold War weapons of the United States]] [[Category:Soviet Union–United States relations]] [[Category:Technological races]] [[Category:Propaganda in the United States]]

'''Bowmanville Foundry Co. Ltd.''' is a [[foundry]] located in [[Bowmanville, Ontario|Bowmanville]], [[Ontario]], Canada. It was established in 1901.
The company has a long history in the manufacture of [[Ductile iron|ductile]], [[gray iron]] and [[malleable iron]] castings.
A 2005 book, ''Iron in the Blood'' {{ISBN|0-9736633-0-8}} by local authors Helen Bajorek MacDonald and Helen Lewis Schmid, discusses the history of the company in the context of family, community, labour and economic history.
The official launch of ''Iron in the Blood'' was mentioned in the Ontario Legislature by [[John O'Toole]], the member for Durham.<ref>[http://www.ontla.on.ca/house-proceedings/transcripts/files_html/2005-04-19_L131.htm Legislative Assembly of Ontario. Transcript of Debates. Issue number: L131 - Tue 19 Apr 2005 ]</ref>
==External links== * [http://www.bowmanvillefoundry.com Bowmanville Foundry]

revision.text:
The '''Cloaca Circi Maximi''' or '''Cloaca Circi''' was a sewer in ancient Rome.
It was originally a small stream fed by various sources from around the [[Porta Capena]] right through the valley between the [[Palatine Hill]] and [[Aventine Hill]], running down to the [[river Tiber]]. According to tradition, games and horse races were held in this vallery from right after the founding of Rome in the 8th century. Over the centuries the [[Circus Maximus]] was built over the stream, with a channel named Euripus running across it halfway and two bridges carrying the track over it. The channel also served as the spina down the middle of the track.
Under [[Julius Caesar]] and [[Augustus]] the circus and its surroundings were greatly enlarged, covering over the channel, which became a sewer. It was connected to a tunnel modelled on that of the [[Cloaca Maxima]] and now terminated on the Tiber upstream of the Cloaca Maxima.
==Bibliography== *[https://books.google.nl/books?id=WxXu83RxSNwC&pg=PA446&lpg=PA446&dq=Cloaca+Circi+Maximi&source=bl&ots=2o-o-DcQ3H&sig=GNuoonvGIerMKp1hqH8ayHDJysg&hl=nl&sa=X&ei=Hx-jVPauLZLaaLXVgMgC&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Cloaca%20Circi%20Maximi&f=false ''Evolution of Water Supply Through the Millennia''], p 446 {{ISBN|9781843395409}} *L. Richardson, jr, ''A New Topographical Dictionary of Ancient Rome'', Baltimore - London 1992. pp.84. {{ISBN|0801843006}}
[[Category:Ancient Roman sewers in Rome]] [[Category:Sewerage]] [[Category:History of water supply and sanitation]]

[[Image:Core drill 06 2005.jpg|right|300px|thumb|Truck mounted core drill]]
A '''core drill''' is a [[drill]] specifically designed to remove a cylinder of material, much like a [[hole saw]]. The material left inside the drill bit is referred to as the ''core''.
Core drills used in metal are called [[annular cutter]]s. Core drills used for concrete are generally called Diamond Core Drills and are water cooled.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.coptool.com/diamond-core-bits-vs-carbide-core-bits-concrete-drilling/ |title=Diamond Core Bits vs Carbide Core Bits |accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref> For drilling masonry, carbide core drills can be used.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.qrents.com/docs/concdrilling.htm |title=Concrete Drilling Tutorial |accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref>
The earliest core drills were those used by the [[ancient Egyptians]], invented in 3000 BC.<ref name="Delleur">{{cite book|author=Jacques W. Delleur|title=The Handbook of Groundwater Engineering, Second Edition|date=12 December 2010|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-8493-4316-2|page=7 in chapter 2}}</ref> Core drills are used for many applications, either where the core needs to be preserved (the drilling apparatus used in obtaining a [[core sample]] is often referred to as a corer), or where drilling can be done more rapidly since much less material needs to be removed than with a standard bit. This is the reason that diamond-tipped core drills are commonly used in construction to create holes for pipes, manholes, and other large-diameter penetrations in [[concrete]] or [[Rock (geology)|stone]].
Core drills are used frequently in [[exploration diamond drilling|mineral exploration]] where the coring may be several hundred to several thousand feet in length. The core samples are recovered and examined by geologists for mineral percentages and stratigraphic contact points. This gives exploration companies the information necessary to begin or abandon mining operations in a particular area.[[File:Oriented Core Goniometer commonly used when logging core.JPG|thumb|Oriented Core Goniometer commonly used when logging core and analyzing contacts and other structural features.]]
Before the start of World War Two, Branner Newsom, a California mining engineer, invented a core drill that could take out large diameter cores up to 16 feet in length for mining shafts. This type of core drill is no longer in use as modern drill technology allows standard drilling to accomplish the same at a much cheaper cost.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Boone |first=Andrew R. |title=He Bores Bigger Holes |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fScDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA104&dq=popular+science+1943+there%27s+one+thrill+no+soldier&hl=en&ei=NlvOTJj2EIPMnAeRwYT-Dw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=true |date=December 1943 |journal=Popular Science |pages=104–107}}</ref>
Core drills come with several power choices including electric, pneumatic, hydraulic (all of which require power sources, such as a generator).
==See also== *[[Annular cutter|Core drills]] ([[annular cutter]]s for metal drilling) * [[Drilling fluid]] *[[Drilling rig]] *[[Exploration diamond drilling]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=January 2015}} {{POV|date=January 2015}} }} {{Infobox company | name = Crunchfish | logo = | image = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | former_name = | type = | industry = [[Technology]] | founded = | founder = | hq_location = [[Malmö]], [[Sweden]] | key_people = | products = [[Software]] | owner = | website = }} '''Crunchfish''' is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] technology company in [[Malmö]] that develops [[gesture recognition]] software for the mobile phone and [[tablet computer|tablet]] market.<ref>[http://hothardware.com/News/Startup-CrunchFish-Builds-Kinect-for-Smartphones/ "Startup CrunchFish Builds 'Kinect' for Smartphones"]. ''Hot Hardware''.</ref> Crunchfish was founded in 2010 with an initial focus to create innovations for the [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] app markets.<ref name="EU-Startups">{{cite web|url=http://www.eu-startups.com/2013/06/mobile-touchless-technology-crunchfish-raises-2-3-million/|title=Mobile touchless technology: Crunchfish raises 2.3 million|date=2013-06-05|publisher=EU-startups.com |accessdate=2013-08-28}}</ref><ref name="Company Overview">{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=184527008|title=Company Overview of Crunchfish ZB|date=2013-02-15|publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=2013-08-23}}</ref> [[Gesture recognition]] using a standard [[webcam]] as main gesture sensor was one of their core innovations and the company is now focusing on touchless [[interaction]] based on camera based gestures.<ref name="innovative Sweden">{{cite web|url=http://eng.si.se/new-innovations-to-innovative-sweden|title=New innovations to Innovative Sweden|date=2013-02-15|publisher=Swedish Institute |accessdate=2013-08-15}}</ref><ref name="innovations">{{cite web|url=http://touchlessgeneration.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/InnovativeSweden_Tokyo_English-05022013-2.pdf|title=Innovatıve Sweden – 20 ınnovatıons for tomorrow´s world|date=2013-02-15|publisher=Swedish Institute|accessdate=2013-08-15}}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In 2013, April, the company was selected a '2013 Red Herring Top 100' company by [[Red Herring (magazine)]].<ref name="RH Top 100 Winner">{{cite web|url=http://www.redherring.com/events/red-herring-europe/2013-red-herring-europe-top-100-2/|title=2013 Red Herring Europe Top 100 Winners |accessdate=2013-07-17 |publisher=Red Herring}}</ref><ref name="Öresund Startups">{{cite web|url=http://oresundstartups.com/tag/crunchfish/ |title=15 ØRESUND STARTUPS ON THE RED HERRING EUROPE TOP 100! |accessdate=2013-08-23 |publisher=Øresund Startups}}</ref> Crunchfish produces gesture sensing software, a set of customized mid-air [[gesture recognition]] solutions, named A3D™, to global mobile device manufacturers and app developers. Crunchfish cooperates with [[smartphone]] manufacturers to enable Crunchfish gesture sensing technology in their partners mobile devices.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.silobreaker.com/crunchfish-11_124061361|title=Crunchfish and Gionee in cooperation to enable touchless interaction in Elife E6 smartphone|date=2013-06-06|publisher=Silobreaker|accessdate=2013-08-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140901053547/http://news.silobreaker.com/crunchfish-11_124061361|archivedate=2014-09-01|df=}}</ref> Crunchfish developed the touchless functions in Chinese Gionee's smartphone Elife E6, launched in [[China]], July, 2013 and in [[India]] and [[Africa]] in August, 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/2013/8/23/gionee_launches_elife_e6_smartphone_in.htm|title=Gionee launches Elife E6 smartphone in Nigeria|date=2013-08-23|publisher=Hispanic Business|accessdate=2013-08-24|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140901053420/http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/2013/8/23/gionee_launches_elife_e6_smartphone_in.htm|archivedate=2014-09-01|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201308220224.html|title=Nigeria: Gionee Launches Flagship Smartphone Elife E6 in Nigeria|date=2013-08-22|publisher=All Africa|accessdate=2013-08-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gadgets.ndtv.com/videos/gionee-elife-e6-and-the-birth-of-a-mobile-phone-285564|title=Gionee Elife E6 and the birth of a mobile phone|date=2013-08-04|publisher=NDTV GADGETS |accessdate=2013-08-24}}</ref>
==Technology==
Crunchfish integrates touchless functions in for e.g. smartphones and the technology is portable to other mobile platform devices. Their [[gesture recognition]] technology can be used in mobile phones, tablets<ref name="share between tablets">{{cite web|url=http://www.ccsinsight.com/our-services/video/1624|title=Mobile World Congress 2013: Crunchfish user interface A Swedish company offers a new way to control devices.|accessdate=2013-08-23|publisher=CCS Insights}}</ref> and DTVs equipped with a front-facing camera. Typical uses for Crunchfish touchless technology are devices in an [[intelligent home]] as smartphones, tablets, [[Digital TV]], games and other home electronics that have a built-in standard camera.<ref name="crunchfish">{{cite web|url=http://crunchfish.com/#our-product |title=TOUCHLESS A3D™ SOFTWARE|date=2013-03-10|publisher=Crunchfish |accessdate=2013-08-21}}</ref> The gesture based functionality adds alternative options to a standard [[touch interface]]. The user can for example put a [[tablet computer|tablet]] in front of him/her and be free to do mid-air gesture with both hands and interacting with a [[Digital media player|media player]] without touching it.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5TFi38FUNjk |title=Touchless Concept Movie - powered by Crunchfish A3D™|date=2013-03-25|publisher=Crunchfish on Youtube |accessdate=2013-08-24}}</ref> Smartphone users can answer and reject phone calls, start slideshows in photo gallery, use video scrubber etc. without touching the device. The device can pause a video playback if the users look away from the screen.
Crunchfish's Touchless A3D software is able to detect and track objects (fingers, hand gestures and face movements) in three dimensions based on the video stream from an embedded standard camera in e.g. a mobile device.<ref name="crunchfish" />

{{confused|discover (disambiguation)}} '''Digital Interactive Systems Corporation''' (or '''DISCover''') is a company specializing in gaming technology for PCs. They are the creators of the DISCover technology which allow [[Personal computer game|PC games]] to be played like a [[video game console]].<ref name="Frictionless Insight Interview">{{cite web|title=Digital Interactive Systems Corp. and DISCover PC Game Consoles|url=http://www.frictionlessinsight.com/archives/2004/02/digital-interac.html|author=Kyle Ackerman|publisher=Frictionless Insight}}</ref> The technology, which features the "Drop and Play" engine, [[Autorun|auto-plays]] CDs or DVDs and automates scripts for installing and updating games.<ref name="GSInterview">{{cite web|title=Q&A: Loren Kaiser on the DISCover engine|url=http://www.gamespot.com/news/6086190.html|author=Tor Thorsen|publisher=GameSpot}}</ref> Consoles with the engine connect to the Internet for game updates.<ref name="GHInterview">{{cite web|title=DISCover PC Game Consoles Interview|url=http://www.gamershell.com/articles/740.html|publisher=Gamers Hell}}</ref> This technology debuted at the 2003 [[Electronic Entertainment Expo]].<ref name="CWHistory">{{cite web|title=DISCover|url=http://darkwatcher.psxfanatics.com/console/discover.htm|publisher=Dark Watcher's Console History}}</ref>
Machines using DISCover technology include the [[Apex Extreme PGC|Apex Extreme]],<ref name="GHInterview" /> [[Alienware]] DHS 2<ref>{{cite web|title=We demand on-demand: Alienware DHS 2 series|url=http://www.cnet.com/4520-10602_1-5619334-1.html|publisher=CNet}}</ref> and DHS 5.<ref>{{cite web|title=Alienware DHS 5 series media center|url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/computing/alienware-dhs-5-series-media-center|publisher=Digital Trends}}</ref>
In August 2007, DISCover announced that their Hardcore White-Label Gaming System, or HAWGS, technology would be used for [[FiringSquad]]'s Ammo [[digital distribution]] service.<ref name="HAWGSpr">{{cite news|title=DISCover's HAWGS(TM) to power PC Game Downloads for FiringSquad.com|url=https://www.forbes.com/businesswire/feeds/businesswire/2007/08/08/businesswire20070808005520r1.html|publisher=Forbes.com|author=DISCover Press Release}} {{Dead link|date=May 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> The following month, on September 2007, the company disclosed the InstaPlay desktop client, which improves the ease of use for accessing games.<ref>{{cite web|title=DISCover's InstaPlay To Launch PC Games Console-Style|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=15624|publisher=Gamasutra}}</ref> DISCover [[chief executive officer]] David Ferrigno addressed Instaplay concerns and comparisons with other digital distribution services such as Direct2Drive and [[Steam (software)|Steam]].<ref>{{cite web|title=DISCover more about InstaPlay - Part 2 (Interview)|url=http://www.generationgamerz.com/v2/insight/discover-more-about-instaplay-part-2-interview.php|publisher=Generation: Gamerz|author=Christophor Rick|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071024205756/http://generationgamerz.com/v2/insight/discover-more-about-instaplay-part-2-interview.php|archivedate=2007-10-24|df=}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Alienware]] *[[Media center (disambiguation)]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.discoverconsole.com/ Official website]
{{sixth generation game consoles}}

'''Digital control''' is a branch of [[control theory]] that uses [[Digital data|digital]] [[computer]]s to act as system controllers. Depending on the requirements, a digital control system can take the form of a [[microcontroller]] to an [[Application-specific integrated circuit|ASIC]] to a standard desktop computer. Since a digital computer is a [[discrete mathematics|discrete]] system, the [[Laplace transform]] is replaced with the [[Z-transform]]. Also since a digital computer has finite precision (''See [[Quantization (signal processing)|quantization]]''), extra care is needed to ensure the error in coefficients, [[Analog to digital converter|A/D conversion]], [[digital to analog converter|D/A conversion]], etc. are not producing undesired or unplanned effects.
The application of digital control can readily be understood in the use of [[feedback]]. Since the creation of the [[Atanasoff–Berry Computer|first digital computer]] in the early 1940s the price of digital computers has dropped considerably, which has made them key pieces to control systems for several reasons: *Inexpensive: under $5 for many microcontrollers *Flexible: easy to configure and reconfigure through software *Scalable: programs can scale to the limits of the memory or storage space without extra cost *Adaptable: parameters of the program can change with time (''See [[adaptive control]]'') *Static operation: digital computers are much less prone to environmental conditions than [[capacitor]]s, [[inductor]]s, etc.
== Digital Controller Implementation == A digital controller is usually cascaded with the plant in a feedback system. The rest of the system can either be digital or analog.
Typically, a digital controller requires: *[[Analog to digital converter|A/D conversion]] to convert analog inputs to machine readable (digital) format *[[Digital to analog converter|D/A conversion]] to convert digital outputs to a form that can be input to a plant (analog) *A program that relates the outputs to the inputs
=== Output Program === *Outputs from the digital controller are functions of current and past input samples, as well as past output samples - this can be implemented by storing relevant values of input and output in registers. The output can then be formed by a weighted sum of these stored values.
The programs can take numerous forms and perform many functions *A [[digital filter]] for [[low-pass filter]]ing *A [[state space (controls)|state space]] model of a system to act as a [[state observer]] *A [[telemetry]] system
=== Stability === Although a controller may be stable when implemented as an analog controller, it could be unstable when implemented as a digital controller due to a large sampling interval. During sampling the aliasing modifies the cutoff parameters. Thus the sample rate characterizes the transient response and stability of the compensated system, and must update the values at the controller input often enough so as to not cause instability.
When substituting the frequency into the z operator, regular stability criteria still apply to discrete control systems. [[Nyquist stability criterion|Nyquist criteria]] apply to z-domain transfer functions as well as being general for complex valued functions. Bode stability criteria apply similarly. [[Jury stability criterion|Jury criterion]] determines the discrete system stability about its characteristic polynomial.
=== Design of digital controller in s-domain === The digital controller can also be designed in the s-domain (continuous). The [[Arnold Tustin|Tustin]] transformation can transform the continuous compensator to the respective digital compensator. The digital compensator will achieve an output which approaches the output of its respective analog controller as the sampling interval is decreased.
<math> s = \frac{2(z-1)}{T(z+1)} </math>
==== Tustin transformation deduction ==== Tustin is the [[Padé table|Padé<sub>(1,1)</sub>]] approximation of the exponential function <math> \begin{align} z &= e^{sT} \end{align} </math> :
: <math> \begin{align} z &= e^{sT} \\ &= \frac{e^{sT/2}}{e^{-sT/2}} \\ &\approx \frac{1 + s T / 2}{1 - s T / 2} \end{align} </math>
And its inverse
: <math> \begin{align} s &= \frac{1}{T} \ln(z) \\ &= \frac{2}{T} \left[\frac{z-1}{z+1} + \frac{1}{3} \left( \frac{z-1}{z+1} \right)^3 + \frac{1}{5} \left( \frac{z-1}{z+1} \right)^5 + \frac{1}{7} \left( \frac{z-1}{z+1} \right)^7 + \cdots \right] \\ &\approx \frac{2}{T} \frac{z - 1}{z + 1} \\ &= \frac{2}{T} \frac{1 - z^{-1}}{1 + z^{-1}} \end{align} </math>
We must never forget that the digital control theory is the technique to design strategies in discrete time, (and/or) quantized amplitude (and/or) in (binary) coded form to be implemented in computer systems (microcontrollers, microprocessors) that will control the analog (continuous in time and amplitude) dynamics of analog systems. From this consideration many errors from classical digital control were identified and solved and new methods were proposed:
*Marcelo Tredinnick and Marcelo Souza and their new type of analog-digital mapping
http://mtc-m18.sid.inpe.br/col/sid.inpe.br/mtc-m18@80/2008/03.17.15.17.24/doc/mirrorget.cgi?languagebutton=pt-BR&metadatarepository=sid.inpe.br/mtc-m18@80/2009/02.09.14.45.33&index=0&choice=full
http://mtc-m05.sid.inpe.br/col/sid.inpe.br/deise/1999/09.14.15.39/doc/homepage.pdf
http://www.sae.org/technical/papers/2002-01-3468
*Yutaka Yamamoto and his "lifting function space model" http://wiener.kuamp.kyoto-u.ac.jp/~yy/Papers/yamamoto_cwi96.pdf *Alexander Sesekin and his studies about impulsive systems. https://www.amazon.com/dp/0792343948
and
*M.U. Akhmetov and his studies about impulsive and pulse control. http://portal.acm.org/author_page.cfm?id=81100182444&coll=GUIDE&dl=GUIDE&trk=0&CFID=27536832&CFTOKEN=71744014
== See also == *[[Sampled data systems]] *[[Adaptive control]] *[[Analog control]] *[[Control theory]] *[[Digital data|Digital]] *[[Feedback]], [[Negative feedback]], [[Positive feedback]] *[[Laplace transform]] *[[Real-time control]] *[[Z-transform]]
==References== {{reflist}} *FRANKLIN, G.F.; POWELL, J.D. Digital control of dynamical systems. USA, California: Addison-Wesley. 1981. {{ISBN|0-201-82054-4}} *KATZ, P. Digital control using microprocessors. Englewood Cliffs: Prentice-Hall, 293p. 1981. *OGATA, K. Discrete-time control systems. Englewood Cliffs: Prentice-Hall,984p. 1987. *PHILLIPS, C.L.; NAGLE, H. T. Digital control system analysis and design. Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey: Prentice Hall International. 1995. *M. Sami Fadali, Antonio Visioli, (2009) "Digital Control Engineering", Academic Press, {{ISBN|978-0-12-374498-2}}. *JURY, E.I. Sampled-data control systems. New-York: John Wiley. 1958.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Digital Control}} [[Category:Control theory]]

page.title: European Federation of Food Science and Technology

revision.comment: Removing [[:c:File:Effostwebsitelogo.jpg|Effostwebsitelogo.jpg]], it has been deleted from Commons by [[:c:User:Jcb|Jcb]] because: Copyright violation; see [[:c:COM:Licensing|Commons:Licensing]] -.
revision.text:
The '''European Federation of Food Science and Technology (EFFoST)''' is a [[Europe]]an-based [[non-governmental organization]] devoted to the advancement of [[food science]] and [[food technology|technology]]. It consists of eighty different societies in 21 different European countries. They are a regional group of the [[International Union of Food Science and Technology]].
==EFFoST's roles== # Increase closer contacts among the [[academic]], [[government]], and [[Industry|industrial]] areas in [[food]]. # Enhance rapid technology transfer to increase [[economic]] competitiveness in [[Europe]]. # Promote [[continuing education]] within food science and technology. # Standardize [[Food politics|food law]] and its enforcement throughout Europe. # Maintain collaborative relationships within the European food industry on Knowledge sharing.
===Publications=== *''[[Innovative Food Science and Emerging Technologies]] (ISFET)'', the official [[scientific journal]] of EFFoST. *''[[Trends in Food Science and Technology]] (TIFS)'', a mini [[peer-review]] scientific journal that is more involved in [[product development]] than basic research. *''Food Processing Intelligence (FPI)'', the official EFFoST book published twice a year on the status of the food industry in Europe. *Position papers on various issues in European food science and technology.
==Executive committee== The Executive Committee consists of a President, Past President, President-Elect, four other elected officials, and twelve Members-At-Large.
==Headquarters== EFFoST is headquartered in [[Wageningen]], [[Netherlands]].
==References== {{portal|Food}} *[http://www.effost.org/ Official website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:European Federation Of Food Science And Technology}} [[Category:Food technology organizations]] [[Category:International scientific organizations of Europe]] [[Category:Organisations based in Gelderland]]

{{Infobox Union |name= F.N.B.P.B |country= [[Burkina Faso]] |affiliation=[[Confédération générale du travail du Burkina]], [[IUF]] |members= |full_name= |native_name=Fédération nationale des boulangers et pâtissiers du Burkina |image= |founded={{Startdate|1960|04|04}} |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office=[[Ouagadougou]], Burkina Faso |people= Djigimdé Tiga, president |website= |footnotes= }} <!-- Include all unused fields for future use. See [[template talk:Infobox Union]] for usage. --> '''''Fédération nationale des boulangers et pâtissiers du Burkina''''' (FNBPB) is a [[trade union]] of bakery workers in [[Burkina Faso]]. The union was founded on April 4, 1960. FNBPB is affiliated to ''[[Confédération générale du travail du Burkina]]'' (CGT-B).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cgtb.bf/struct.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-09-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706142823/http://www.cgtb.bf/struct.htm |archivedate=2011-07-06 |df= }}</ref> Djigimdé Tiga is the president of FNBPB.<ref>http://www.evenement-bf.net/pages/contre_jour_158.htm</ref>
FNBPB is a member of the [[International Union of Food, Agricultural, Hotel, Restaurant, Catering, Tobacco and Allied Workers' Association]].<ref>http://www.iufdocuments.org/cgi-bin/dbman/db.cgi?db=default&uid=default&view_records=1&ID=*&sb=2&nh=10</ref>
