'''George W. Snyder''' (1780–1841) was a [[watchmaker]] and [[inventor]].{{cite book|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/58929973|title=George Reynolds Snyder, Sr|last=|first=|year=2012|work=Find A Grave|page=|accessdate=June 1, 2012}} George W. Snyder was a 19th-century reel maker from [[Paris, Kentucky|Paris]], [[Kentucky]]. He is credited for inventing the very first American-made [[fishing reel]] in 1820. ==George Snyder (fly reels)== ===Kentucky Reel=== Snyder's reel was designed for fly fishing, and named the Kentucky Reel. Without [[patent]] or trademark protection, the Kentucky reel was quickly copied by many others, including Meek, Milam, Sage, Hardman and Gayle. These artisans were trained in Jewelry fabrication and were experienced in cutting gears, constructing small parts, and doing precision work. In time, the Kentucky Reel was mass-produced by the emerging factories located in the Northeast, where they could be produced at a fraction of the cost and time required for hand-built construction. The availability of more affordable fly reels greatly stimulated the sales and popularity of fly fishing equipment, and was soon applied to bait casting reels, resulting in a surge in the popularity of fishing as a pastime among all levels of American society.Land, Bill. ORCA, "Reel History." Accessed December 6, 2011. http://orcaonline.org/reel_history.htm
George Snyder was born in the same county as [[Daniel Boone]]—[[Bucks County, Pennsylvania|Bucks, Pa]]. He later went to [[Paris, Kentucky|Paris, Ky]]., then called Hopewell, about 1803, and died there on February 10, 1841, aged sixty years. He was a skillful watchmaker and silversmith; being a good practical angler, and seeing the necessity for a rapid multiplying reel for black-bass fishing with the live minnow, he proceeded to invent one. Snyder's first reel was made for his own use, about 1810. He afterward made reels for members of his club, and others.Henshall. James A., "Evolution of the 'Kentucky Reel'"
==The New York Reel== During the middle of the 19th century, another fly reel was invented in New York City. The "New York Reel" was usually made out of brass or nickel silver, and it was much heavier than the Kentucky Reel. It had a serpentine crank or a "ball-handle".Kerr, Charles. "Learning How to Fish." Accessed December 6, 2011. http://www.howtofishguide.com/tackle/history-fishing-reel. ==See also== * [[Fishing reel]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{fishing rod topics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Snyder, George}} [[Category:Fishing equipment]] [[Category:19th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Kentucky]] [[Category:People from Paris, Kentucky]] [[Category:1780 births]] [[Category:1841 deaths]]

revision.comment: /* History */[[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], replaced: according → according to the using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
[[File:Gutenberg-Museum Mainz 585-vh.jpg|thumb|House "Zum Römischen Kaiser", today: Gutenberg Museum]] [[Image:B42-print.jpg|thumb|A type facsimile of a page from the Gutenberg Bible, printed at the museum]] [[Image:ZumRomischenKaiser.JPG|thumb|Older part of the Gutenberg Museum in the ''Zum Römischen Kaiser'' house, Mainz]] The '''Gutenberg Museum''' is one of the oldest museums of printing in the world, located opposite the [[Mainz Cathedral|cathedral]] in the old part of [[Mainz]], Germany. It is named after [[Johannes Gutenberg]], the inventor of printing from movable metal type in Western Europe. The collections include printing equipment and examples of printed materials from many cultures.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.allgemeine-zeitung.de/region/mainz/meldungen/11896833.htm |title=Mainz: Ausstellung im Gutenberg-Museum wird nach großem Zuspruch bis August verlängert |last=Mikutta |first=Sandra |date=24 April 2012 |work=[[Allgemeine Zeitung (Mainz)|Allgemeine Zeitung]] |trans-title=Exhibition at the Gutenberg Museum will be extended until August to enthusiastic response |language=German |accessdate=15 May 2012 |location=Mainz}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.allgemeine-zeitung.de/region/mainz/meldungen/11879701.htm |title=Gutenberg-Museum Mainz: Stadt begrüßt bürgerliches Engagement |last=Jacobs |first=Michael |date=19 April 2012 |work=[[Allgemeine Zeitung (Mainz)|Allgemeine Zeitung]] |trans-title=Gutenberg Museum in Mainz: City welcomes civic engagement |language=German |accessdate=15 May 2012 |location=Mainz}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wiesbadener-kurier.de/region/kultur/ausstellungen/11901687.htm |title=Rasante Rallye durch Lettern-Welt |last=Schröder |first=Andreas |date=25 April 2012 |work=Wiesbadener Kurier |trans-title=Fast-paced rally world by letters |language=German |accessdate=15 May 2012 |location=Mainz}}</ref>
==History== A group of people founded the museum in 1900, 500 years after [[Johannes Gutenberg]]’s birth, to honor the inventor and present his technical and artistic achievements to the public at large. They also aimed to exhibit the writing and printing of as many different cultures as possible.
Publishers, manufacturers of printing machines and printing houses donated books, apparatus and machines, which formed the basis of the collection. In its first few years the museum was part of the city library, meaning that the most beautiful and characteristic volumes from the library’s extensive collection could be requisitioned for the museum. Visitors were thus presented with a survey of almost 500 years of the printed book. In time the museum expanded to include sections on printing techniques, book art, job printing and ex-libris, graphics and posters, paper, the history of writing of all cultures of the world and modern artists’ books.
The Gutenberg Museum was originally laid out in two rooms at the Kurfürstliches Schloß ([[Electoral Palace Mainz]]), which also accommodated the city library. The museum moved into the new library building on the Rheinallee in 1912. The same year, 1925, saw the installation of a reconstruction of Gutenberg’s workshop which soon became one of the museum’s main attractions. Type founding, typesetting and printing could now be demonstrated visually. The replica of Gutenberg’s printing press, rebuilt according to the 15th- and 16th-century woodcuts, proved an object of great interest to visitors and was henceforth shown at a large number of exhibitions all over the world.
In 1927 the museum was able to move into the ''[[Zum Römischen Kaiser]]'' (1664), one of the most beautiful buildings in Mainz. This is now where the museum’s administration, the restoration workshop, library and Gutenberg Society are housed. The Late Renaissance building was heavily bombed in 1945; the museum’s contents had been stored in a safe place and thus remained intact. In 1962, the restoration of the Römischer Kaiser was complete. A new, modern exhibition building was also opened in the place where once the guest house ''König von England'' stood.
==Acquisitions== The museum made several important acquisitions in the following years, among them a second [[Gutenberg Bible]], the Shuckburgh Bible in two volumes (1978), and two block books printed using wooden formes and today extremely rare. Another major change was the introduction of the museum’s educational unit in 1989. In 2000, the old museum building was restored and extended.
== See also == *[[Gutenberg-Jahrbuch]]
==References== {{Reflist}} * Hans Adolf Halbey, Elke Schutt-Kehm, Rolf Stümpel: ''Buchkultur aus Mainz. Schrift Druck Buch im Gutenberg Museum.'' Verlag Philipp von Zabern, Magonza 1993. {{ISBN|3-8053-0823-X}} * Anton M. Keim: ''Mehr als zwei „Denkmäler“. Neunzig Jahre Weltmusum der Druckkunst und internationale Gutenberg-Gesellschaft Mainz.'' Verlag der Gutenberg-Gesellschaft, Mainz 1991, {{ISBN|3-7755-2109-7}} (''Kleiner Druck der Gutenberg-Gesellschaft'' 109), (Deutsche Fassung auch in: ''Imprimatur.'' NF 14, 1991, {{ISSN|0073-5620}}, S. 83–108).
==External links== {{Commons category|Gutenberg Museum}} * [http://www.gutenberg-museum.de/?language=e Gutenberg Museum website] * {{de icon}} [http://www.gutenberg-bibliothek.de/ Gutenberg Library website]
{{Coord|49|59|59|N|8|16|31|E|region:DE-RP_type:landmark|display=title}}

{{short description|capitalist dynasty}} {{Infobox family |name=Hawks |region={{flag|England}} |members= <small> *Sir Robert Shafto Hawks (1768 - 1840) *Joseph Hawks {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|DL|JP}} (1791 - 1873), Sheriff of Newcastle *George Hawks {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|DL|JP}}, (1801 - 1863), Grand Master of the [[Knights Templar (Freemasonry)]], and Mayor of Gateshead *Mary Hawks (b. 1829), wife of [[Richard Clement Moody]] *[[Richard Stanley Hawks Moody|Colonel Richard Stanley Hawks Moody CB]] (1854 - 1930) </small> |connectedmembers= <small> *[[Richard Clement Moody|Major-General Richard Clement Moody]] *[[Robert Stirling Newall]] *[[William Hutt (politician)|Sir William Hutt]] *[[William Crawshay II]] </small> |estate=[[Pembroke Square, London|Pembroke Square, Kensington]] |footnotes=One of the largest and most powerful British industrial dynasties of the [[Industrial Revolution]]. It owned several companies in [[Northern England|the North]] and the [[City of London]], from which it exported worldwide, and employed over 2000 persons. }}
The '''Hawks family''' (c.1750 – 1889) was one of the largest and most powerful British dynasties to arise during the [[Industrial Revolution|British Industrial Revolution]]. It owned several companies in the [[Northern England|North]] and the [[City of London]] - including '''Hawks and Co.''', '''Hawks, Crawshay, and Stanley''', and '''Hawks, Crawshay and Sons''' - all of which featured the Hawks name in the company name<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/Hawks_and_Co|title=Hawks and Co, Grace's Guide to British Industrial History|accessdate=6 December 2016}}</ref> and had iron manufacture and engineering as their main enterprises.
The Hawks company reached the apogee of its power in the early [[Victorian period]], during which it employed over 2000 persons, and its reputation for engineering and bridge building was worldwide. Its [[Gateshead]] factories were termed New Deptford and New Woolwich after the location of two of its warehouses on the [[River Thames]], [[Deptford]] and [[Woolwich]]. The company owned its own ships, which it used to transport its manufacture. It built the striking [[High Level Bridge]] across the [[River Tyne]] that was opened by [[Queen Victoria]] in 1849, bridges as far afield as [[Constantinople]] and [[India]], and lighthouses in [[France]]. It produced [[ironclad warships]] and other materials for the [[Royal Navy]] to exponential profits during the [[Napoleonic Wars]] and completed several large contracts for the [[East India Company]]. It also produced the first [[iron]] boat, the Vulcan, in 1821.
Several members of the Hawks family were involved in [[merchant banking]], several in [[Freemasonry]], and several in the advocacy of [[Whigs (British political party)|Whig free-trade politics]]. Notable members included Sir Robert Shafto Hawks (1768-1840); Joseph Hawks {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|DL|JP}} (1791-1873), merchant banker and Sheriff of Newcastle; George Hawks (1801-1863), [[Freemason]] and [[Knights Templar (Freemasonry)|Grand Master of the Grand Cross Chapter of the Holy Temple of Jerusalem (Knights Templar)]], and Mayor of Gateshead; Mary Hawks (b.1829), who was the wife of [[Richard Clement Moody]], the founder of [[British Columbia]]; and [[Richard Stanley Hawks Moody|Colonel Richard Stanley Hawks Moody]] (1854-1930).
The family developed areas of [[London|West London]], including [[Pembroke Square, London|Pembroke Square, Kensington]]. [[File:Newcastle Tyne Bridges, 19th June 1967.jpg|thumb| The [[High Level Bridge]] (left) built by the Hawks dynasty]]
The poet [[Joseph Skipsey]] worked for the Hawks company, at their Gateshead ironworks, from 1859 to 1863, until one of his children was killed in a fatal accident at the works in 1863. The job was obtained for Skipsey by [[James Thomas Clephan]], the editor of the ''Gateshead Observer''.
==Foundation==
The Hawks company was established by William Hawks (1708–1755), who worked for [[Ambrose Crowley|Sir Ambrose Crowley]], [[Sheriff of London]]. In the late 1740s, Hawks established a set of workshops on waste ground along the river at Gateshead. When Hawks died - at Gateshead on 23 February 1755 - the works passed to the eldest son, William Hawks (bap. 1730, d. 1810), who, with his first wife, Elizabeth Dixon, established the Hawks' industrial empire. William (d.1810) formed a partnership with Thomas Longridge (bap. 1751, d. 1803), in 1770, and shortly afterwards acquired a plating forge at [[Beamish, County Durham]], which was the first of four separate metalworking sites operated by Hawks and Longridge along Beamish Burn.<ref name="Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Hawks family"/>
In the 1780s, a forge at Lumley, in [[County Durham]], and slitting and rolling mills, on the [[River Blyth, Northumberland|River Blyth]] in Northumberland, were acquired by the company.<ref name="Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Hawks family">[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]], Hawks family</ref>[[File:Highlevelqueenvic.png|thumb|The inauguration of the High Level Bridge by HM Queen Victoria on 28 September 1849]]
By 1790, the works at Gateshead consisted of a substantial industrial complex that produced steel, anchors, heavy chains, steam-engine components, and a great diversity of smaller iron wares. The supply of ironware to the [[Board of Admiralty]] became a speciality. The firm's products were transported by the Gordon and Stanley families, the latter of whom had links to the old ordnance industry of the [[Weald]] and the naval yards of the [[River Thames]] and the [[Medway]].<ref name="Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Hawks family"/> The family also owned the [[Bedlington Ironworks]] during this period.<ref name="Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Hawks family"/>
==Height: 1810 - 1880== On 4 December 1810, the estate and works of William Hawks passed to his surviving sons: George Hawks (1766–1820) of Blackheath, Sir Robert Shafto Hawks (1768–1840), and John Hawks (1770–1830).<ref name="Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Hawks family"/>
The Hawks Company built Hawks Cottages in the 1830s in the Saltmeadows district of Gateshead for its workers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.co.uk/news/north-east-news/statue-of-the-week-4613575|title=The Journal, Statue of the Week, George Hawks|accessdate=6 December 2016}}</ref>
The Hawks works covered 44 acres by the end of the 1830s, and employed between 800 and 900 persons.<ref name="Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Hawks family"/> At the time of the visit of the British Association to Newcastle in 1863, it employed 1500 people, and owned 92 marine engines and 58 land engines, which together provided 5000 horse power, and 33 puddling furnaces.<ref>{{cite book | title = The Monthly Chronicle of North Country Lore and Legend| page=30 | year=1887}}</ref>
The family's New Greenwich [[ironworks]] at [[Gateshead]] was the town's largest employer until its closure, in mysterious circumstances, in 1889.<ref name="Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Hawks family"/>
The poet [[Joseph Skipsey]] worked for the Hawks company, at their Gateshead ironworks, from 1859 to 1863, until one of his children was killed in a fatal accident at the works in 1863. The job was obtained for Skipsey by [[James Thomas Clephan]], the editor of the ''Gateshead Observer''.<ref name=Journal-16-03-2012Misc>{{cite web|title= Life of Tyneside pitman poet Joseph Skipsey to be celebrated –The Journal 16 March 2012|url=http://www.journallive.co.uk/north-east-news/todays-news/2012/03/16/life-of-tyneside-pitman-poet-joseph-skipsey-to-be-celebrated-61634-30548754/#ixzz21uxo7BqV}}</ref> [[File:HMSWarrior.JPG|thumb|The Hawks company produced numerous [[ironclad warships]] for the [[Royal Navy]] and the [[East India Company]].]]
==Works== ===The Vulcan=== The first iron boat to be built, which was a rowing boat that was named the Vulcan, was constructed, in 1821, at the Hawks's ironworks. When Sir Robert Shafto Hawks was informed of the purpose for which Samuel Tyne, the boat's inventor, had purchased iron from the Hawks company, he proffered all of the iron required for the task free of charge. Sir Robert arranged for cannons to be fired at the launch of the boat, which subsequently won races against wooden boats of the same capacity.<ref>{{cite book | title = The Monthly Chronicle of North Country Lore and Legend| page=30 | year=1887}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | title = The Monthly Chronicle of North Country Lore and Legend| page=92 | year=1887}}</ref>
However, on [[Feast of the Ascension|Ascension Day]], 1826, when, laden with 12 persons including the rowers of the Vulcan, a boat accompanying the Mayor's barge down the river was hit by a steam vessel, two of the Vulcan's rowers were killed, and the Vulcan was subsequently abandoned.<ref>{{cite book | title = The Monthly Chronicle of North Country Lore and Legend| page=30 | year=1887}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | title = The Monthly Chronicle of North Country Lore and Legend| page=92 | year=1887}}</ref>
===Products=== At around the year 1842, the Hawks company erected a cast iron bridge at [[York]], which spans the river [[River Ouse, Yorkshire|Ouse]] in one arch of 172 feet in width. They company also reconstructed the [[Rowland Burdon (died 1838)|Rowland Burdon]] iron bridge at [[Sunderland, Tyne and Wear|Sunderland]], which consists of a single arch of a width of 237 feet. The company also constructed the wrought iron gates for the [[Northumberland]] Docks; the iron lighthouses at [[Gunfleet]], [[Harwich]], and [[Calais]]; and the iron pier at [[Madras]].<ref>{{cite book | title = The Monthly Chronicle of North Country Lore and Legend| page=30 | year=1887}}</ref> The company also built bridges in [[Constantinople]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Welford| first = Richard | title = Monuments and Tombstones in the Church of St. Nicholas, Newcastle-upon-Tyne| page=21 | year=1880}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Middlebrook| first = S. | title = Newcastle-upon-Tyne. Its Growth and Achievement| page=133 | year=1950}}</ref> Sir Robert Hawks financed the construction of [[St John's Church, Gateshead Fell]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gateshead-history.com/low-fell.html|title=History of Low Fell, Gateshead History|accessdate=6 December 2016}}</ref> The company built the [[High Level Bridge]] over the Tyne, which consisted of 5050 tons of iron. George Hawks, the Mayor of Gateshead (see below), drove in the last key of the structure on 7 June 1849.<ref>{{cite book | title = The Monthly Chronicle of North Country Lore and Legend| page=30 | year=1887}}</ref> The bridge was opened by [[Queen Victoria]] later that year.<ref name="Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Hawks family"/> [[File:Highlevelroadway.png|thumb|The carriageway level of the High Level Bridge]]
The company produced [[ironclad warships]] and other materials for the [[Royal Navy]] to exponential profits during the [[Napoleonic Wars]], <ref>{{cite book | last = Welford| first = Richard | title = Monuments and Tombstones in the Church of St. Nicholas, Newcastle-upon-Tyne| page=21 | year=1880}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Middlebrook| first = S. | title = Newcastle-upon-Tyne. Its Growth and Achievement| page=133 | year=1950}}</ref> and completed several large contracts for the [[East India Company]]<ref>{{cite book | title = The Monthly Chronicle of North Country Lore and Legend| page=29 | year=1887}}</ref> It also built paddle steamers and hydraulic dredgers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.co.uk/news/north-east-news/statue-of-the-week-4613575|title=The Journal, Statue of the Week, George Hawks|accessdate=6 December 2016}}</ref>
===Property=== The family developed also developed areas of [[London]], including [[Pembroke Square, London|Pembroke Square, Kensington]].<ref>{{cite book |last= Welford |first= Richard |title= Survey of London: Volume 42 |volume= Kensington Square To Earl's Court: The Edwardes Estate: Pembroke Square, Pembroke Gardens and Pembroke Road area |page= 268-282 |publisher= London County Council |year= 1986}}</ref> [[File:Pembroke Square, London 11.JPG|thumb|[[Pembroke Square, London|Pembroke Square, Kensington]] was developed by the Hawks dynasty]]
==Notable members==
===Sir Robert Shafto Hawks (1768-1840)===
Robert Shafto Hawks became the director of the firm subsequent to the death of his father. He was knighted by the [[George IV of the United Kingdom|Prince Regent]], in 1817, for his role in suppressing riots in the winter of that year.<ref name="Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Hawks family"/> Shafto Hawks was involved in [[Freemasonry]] and served as Worshipful Master of the oldest lodge in Northumberland.<ref>{{cite book|title=Northumbrian Masonry, and the Development of the Craft in England|last=Strachan|first=John|year=1898|publisher=G. Kenning|page=130}}</ref>
Shafto Hawks is commemorated in [[Newcastle Cathedral]], and his portrait hangs in [[Shipley Art Gallery]].
Sir Robert married Hannah Pembroke Akenhead (1766 - 1863) in 1790 and had two sons.<ref>{{cite book | last = Skempton| first = A.W. | title = A Biographical Dictionary of Civil Engineers in Great Britain and Ireland: 1500-1830| page=306 - 308 | publisher=Thomas Telford| year=2002}}</ref> One son, William, entered the church. Sir Robert and Lady Hannah's blind son, David, was a [[List of child music prodigies|musical prodigy]] who composed and published marches for military bands at 9 years of age. He later specialized in the composition of [[Tyrol (state)|Tyrolean]], [[Scotland|Scottish]], and [[Wales|Welsh]] [[Air (music)|airs]]. He was described as showing 'a most amazing proof of musical genius and early proficiency' when 17 years of age <ref>{{cite book | last = Bath| first = Jo | title = The Gateshead Book of Days| page=January 25, 1824| publisher=The History Press| year=2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Lang| first = A | title = The St Mary's Story| publisher=Gateshead Council| year=2009}}</ref> and as a 'true musical genius'.<ref>{{cite book | title = The Monthly Chronicle of North Country Lore and Legend| page=29 | year=1887}}</ref>
===George Hawks (1801-1863)===
Sir Robert's nephew George Hawks (1801–1863) {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|JP|DL}}, of Redheugh Hall, succeeded him as head of the Hawks company. George Hawks was an advocate of free-trade, and a vehement supporter of the [[Whigs (British political party)|Whigs]] and [[William Hutt (politician)|Sir William Hutt MP]], who was MP for Gateshead after 1841.<ref name="Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Hawks family"/> Hutt campaigned to have George Hawks knighted. Hawks's home, Redheugh Hall, became one of the organizing centres of [[Whigs (British political party)|Liberalism]] in the north east of England.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pmsa.org.uk/pmsa-database/9633/|title=Monument to George Hawks, Public Memorial and Sculpture Association| accessdate=6 December 2016}}</ref><ref name="Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Hawks family"/>
George Hawks served as the first [[Mayor of Gateshead]] in 1836, and, subsequently, served in the same position again in 1848 and 1849.<ref name="Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Hawks family"/>
George Hawks was extensively involved in [[Freemasonry]]. George Hawks served as [[Knights Templar (Freemasonry)|Grand Master of the Grand Cross Chapter of the Holy Temple of Jerusalem (Knights Templar)]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://masonicperiodicals.org/static/media/periodicals/041-FRM-1858-04-01-002-SINGLE-ORIGNAME_00002_9SPLIT.PDF |title=No.XIV, -April 7, 1858, Knights Templar|page=713}}</ref> He also served as Past Master of the Lodge of Newcastle upon Tyne, Deputy of the Provincial Grand Lodge of Northumberland, and a Full Affiliated Member of The Celtic Lodge of Edinburgh and Leith, No.291. Hawks was made a [[Freemason]] in Guernsey, and was later described as 'an excellent mason'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thecelticlodge.org/archive-minutes-celtic-lodge-/-minutes-of-c-l-291-from-1847-1850|title=The Celtic Lodge of Edinburgh and Leith, No.291., Minutes 1847-1850.}}</ref>
===Joseph Hawks (1791-1873)===
Sir Robert's nephew Joseph Hawks, {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|JP|DL}}, of Jesmond House, Newcastle upon Tyne, was a [[merchant banker]] who served as [[Sheriff]] of [[Newcastle-upon-Tyne|Newcastle]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Fordyce| first = T. | title = Local Records : or, Historical Register of Remarkable Events, which have occurred in Northumberland and Durham, Newcastle-upon-Tyne, and Berwick-upon-Tweed from the Earliest Period of Authentic Record to the Present Time [...]| page=172 | publisher=T. Fordyce, Newcastle upon Tyne| year=1866}}</ref> He married Mary Elizabeth Boyd, daughter of William Boyd, merchant banker of the prominent Boyd merchant banking family<ref>Howard, Joseph Jackson (1893–1906). Heraldic Visitation of England and Wales. 8. p. 161-164.</ref> that founded the bank of Newcastle.<ref>A History of Banks, Bankers, & Banking in Northumberland, Durham, and North Yorkshire, Illustrating the Commercial Development of the North of England, from 1755 to 1894</ref> Mary Boyd's brother was industrialist [[Edward Fenwick Boyd]]. William Boyd was a descendant of [[Sir Thomas Liddell, 1st Baronet|Sir Francis Liddell]],<ref name="Hylton Longstaffe, Pedigree of Chaytor">{{cite book|last=Hylton Longstaffe|first=W|title=The House of Clervaux, Its Descents and Alliances|pages=Pedigree of Chaytor|publisher=G. Bouchier Richardson, Newcastle upon Tyne|year=1852}}</ref> the second son of [[Sir Thomas Liddell, 1st Baronet]], whose family monopolized the government of the [[North of England]] in the 16th and 17th centuries, and his second wife, Frances Forster, previously wife of Nicholas Forster of [[Bamburgh Castle]], Northumberland, and daughter of [[Chaytor baronets|Sir William Chaytor of Croft]].<ref name="Hylton Longstaffe, Pedigree of Chaytor">{{cite book|last=Hylton Longstaffe|first=W|title=The House of Clervaux, Its Descents and Alliances|pages=Pedigree of Chaytor|publisher=G. Bouchier Richardson, Newcastle upon Tyne|year=1852}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Burke|first=John|title=A Visitation of the Seats and Arms of the Noblemen and Gentlemen of Great Britain, Volume 1|year=1852|publisher=Colburn & Co, London |page=60 in section ‘A Visitation of Arms’}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Hutchinson|first=William|title=The History and Antiquities of the County Palatine of Durham, Volume 2|year=1787|publisher=S. Hodgson and Robinsons, Durham |page=Footnote to p419: ‘By the Will of Sir Tho. Liddell…’}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Raine| first = James | title = The History and Antiquities of North Durham, History and Pedigree of Forster Family| page=306 - 310 | publisher=John Bowyer Nichols & Son, London| year=1852}}</ref>
===Mary Hawks, later Moody (b.1829)===
Joseph's daughter, Mary Susannah Hawks, married [[Richard Clement Moody]], the founder of [[British Columbia]]. Her 13 children included Josephine 'Zeffie' Moody, who married Arthur Newall,<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://api.ning.com/files/Pwx68GFnuuBDqb1wRfgoMEsaVMh9l6ZFcQE1PZO3RYpLzYY8Iwih2339ABomznAmgVyXNL97XKu75RxFRY8u31wYPO9QaQoI/MOODYAlbumINFO2a.pdf|title=The Photographic Album of Richard Clement Moody, Royal British Columbia Museum}}</ref> son of [[Robert Stirling Newall]], a close business associate of the Hawks family, [[Richard Stanley Hawks Moody|Colonel Richard Stanley Hawks Moody]], and [[Colonel (British Army)|Colonel]] Henry de Clervaulx Moody. Richard Clement Moody named the 400-foot hill in Port Coquitlam, British Columbia, "Mary Hill" after his wife, Mary. The Royal British Columbia Museum possesses a trove of 42 letters written by Mary Moody from various colonies of the [[British Empire]], mostly from the [[Colony of British Columbia (1858–66)]], to her mother and her sister, Emily Hawks, in England.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://search-bcarchives.royalbcmuseum.bc.ca/Document/Finding_Aids_Atom/MS-0001_to_MS-0500/ms-0060.pdf|title=Letters of Mary Moody, Royal British Columbia Museum Archives|publisher=|accessdate=4 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Neuman| first = T | title = The [[London Gazette]] for the Year 1838, Part 2.| page=1544 | publisher=Robert George Clarke, London| year=1838}}</ref> Mary Moody was highly literate, having been tutored in literature, penmanship, and French, and her letters have been of great interest to scholars studying the perspective of the English ruling class in the colonies of the [[British Empire]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/article/503247|title=Imperial Relations: Histories of family in the British Empire, Esme Cleall, Laura Ishiguro, and Emily J. Manktelow|publisher=Project Muse|accessdate=4 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://open.library.ubc.ca/collections/bch/items/1.0190709|title=The University of British Columbia, Records of the British Columbia Historical Association, British Columbia Historical News|publisher=British Columbia Historical Association |accessdate=4 July 2016}}</ref>
===Richard Stanley Hawks Moody (1854-1930)=== {{Main article|Richard Stanley Hawks Moody}} [[File:Photograph_of_Richard_Stanley_Hawks_Moody_(b.1854),_3rd_Regiment_of_Foot,_c.1885.png|thumb|right|[[Richard Stanley Hawks Moody|Colonel Richard Stanley Hawks Moody, CB]] (1854 - 1930).]] [[Colonel (British Army)|Colonel]] Richard Stanley Hawks Moody {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|CB}} was a distinguished officer of the [[British Army]].<ref name="Who Was Who, Richard Stanley Hawks Moody">{{cite web|url=http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/article/oupww/whowaswho/U214312|title=Entry for MOODY, Colonel Richard Stanley Hawks, in ''Who Was Who'' (A & C Black, Bloomsbury Publishing plc, 1920–2016)}}</ref>
==Decline==
Hannah, Lady Hawks (d. 1863), the widow of Sir Robert Shafto Hawks, and her two sons sold their shares, in 1840, to George Crawshay a member of a prominent iron-making family of south Wales,. George Crawshay had been bought out of his family's iron merchanting business in London by his brother, [[William Crawshay II]]. The business developed by William Hawks had been divided between his three eldest surviving sons in 1810. When he was able to acquire the shares of Joseph Hawks, the only surviving son of George Hawks of Blackheath, he obtained a second third of the company. The Bedlington works passed eventually to a cousin of the Hawkses, Michael Longridge (1785–1853), a pioneer of railway technology, and an associate of [[Robert Stephenson]], under whose superintendence the works became a training ground for a generation of celebrated engineers; including Sir [[Daniel Gooch]].<ref name="Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Hawks family"/>
The dominant influence over the firm of Hawks, Crawshay & Sons in its last years was George Crawshay (1821–1896), the son of George Crawshay and his wife, Like George Hawks, George Crawshay became a considerable political figure in the north-east. However, Crawshay's management of the company was incompetent: he devoted much of his time to political pursuits and failed to modernize the company, which manufactured diverse products by diverse processes, to enable it to outcompete the newer specialist companies. The specialist companies, such as those owned by [[William Armstrong, 1st Baron Armstrong]] and the William Galloway, the nail manufacturer, flourished as the Hawks company declined.<ref name="Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Hawks family"/>
In 1889, New Greenwich was suddenly closed, and Hawks, Crawshay, and Sons was liquidated. The circumstances surrounding the closure are mysterious: all of the firm's creditors were paid in full, but every single document of the company's archive was systematically destroyed by burning.<ref name="Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Hawks family"/><ref>{{cite journal |last=Rennison |first=Robert |last2=Scott |first2=Austin |date=2008 |title=The Ironworks of Hawks Crawshay & Sons, Gateshead: 1748–1889|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1179/175035208X258329?journalCode=yhet19 |journal=Transactions of the Newcomen Society |volume=78 |issue=1 |pages= |doi= |access-date=5 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Gateshead Metropolitan Borough Council| first = A.W. | title = A Short History of Gateshead| page=| publisher=| year=1998}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book|title=Entry for Hawks family in ''[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]''}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/Hawks_and_Co|title=''Hawks and Co.,'' Grace's Guide to British Industrial History|accessdate=6 December 2016}} *{{cite journal |last=Rennison |first=Robert |last2=Scott |first2=Austin |date=2008 |title=''The Ironworks of Hawks Crawshay & Sons, Gateshead: 1748–1889''|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1179/175035208X258329?journalCode=yhet19 |journal=Transactions of the Newcomen Society |volume=78 |issue=1 |pages= |doi= |access-date=5 March 2017 }} *{{cite book | last = Skempton| first = A.W. | title = ''A Biographical Dictionary of Civil Engineers in Great Britain and Ireland: 1500-1830''| page=306 - 308 | publisher=Thomas Telford| year=2002}} *{{cite book | last = Gateshead Metropolitan Borough Council| first = A.W. | title =''A Short History of Gateshead''| page=| publisher=| year=1998}} *{{cite web|url=http://search-bcarchives.royalbcmuseum.bc.ca/Document/Finding_Aids_Atom/MS-0001_to_MS-0500/ms-0060.pdf|title=Letters of Mary Moody, Royal British Columbia Museum Archives|publisher=|accessdate=6 December 2016}} *{{cite web|url=http://api.ning.com/files/Pwx68GFnuuBDqb1wRfgoMEsaVMh9l6ZFcQE1PZO3RYpLzYY8Iwih2339ABomznAmgVyXNL97XKu75RxFRY8u31wYPO9QaQoI/MOODYAlbumINFO2a.pdf|title=The Photographic Album of Richard Clement Moody, Royal British Columbia Museum}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/article/oupww/whowaswho/U214312|title=Entry for MOODY, Colonel Richard Stanley Hawks, in ''Who Was Who'' (A & C Black, Bloomsbury Publishing plc, 1920–2016)}}
[[Category:English families]] [[Category:Industrial Revolution]] [[Category:History of Newcastle upon Tyne]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Northumberland]] [[Category:History of Northumberland]] [[Category:Industrial history of England]] [[Category:Ironworks and steelworks in England]] [[Category:History of rail transport in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Railway lines in North East England]] [[Category:Rail transport in Northumberland]]

The '''Hunter process''' was the first industrial process to produce pure ductile metallic [[titanium]]. It was invented in 1910 by [[Matthew A. Hunter]], a [[chemist]] born in New Zealand, who worked in the US.<ref> M. A. Hunter "Metallic Titanium" J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1910, pp 330–336. {{DOI|10.1021/ja01921a006}}</ref> The process involves reducing [[titanium tetrachloride]] (TiCl<sub>4</sub>) with [[sodium]] (Na) in a batch reactor with an inert atmosphere at a temperature of 1,000°C. Dilute hydrochloric acid is then used to leach the salt from the product.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Hunter process - Oxford Reference|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780199651450.001.0001/acref-9780199651450-e-1447|language=en|doi=10.1093/acref/9780199651450.001.0001/acref-9780199651450-e-1447}}</ref> :TiCl<sub>4</sub> + 4 Na → 4 NaCl + Ti
Prior to the Hunter process, all efforts to produce Ti metal afforded highly impure material, often [[titanium nitride]] (which resembles a metal). The Hunter process was replaced by the more economical [[Kroll process]] in the 1940s. In the Kroll Process, TiCl<sub>4</sub> is reduced by [[magnesium]].<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|authors=Heinz Sibum, Volker Günther, Oskar Roidl, Fathi Habashi, Hans Uwe Wolf|title=Titanium, Titanium Alloys, and Titanium Compounds|encyclopedia=Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry|year=2005|publisher=Wiley-VCH|location=Weinheim|doi=10.1002/14356007.a27_095}}</ref>
==References== <references />

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=September 2012}} [[File:Csöves villámfeszítő.png|thumb|Jedlik's tubular voltage generator]] An '''impulse generator''' is an electrical apparatus which produces very short high-voltage or high-current surges. Such devices can be classified into two types: impulse voltage generators and impulse current generators. High impulse voltages are used to test the strength of electric power equipment against lightning and switching surges. Also, steep-front impulse voltages are sometimes used in nuclear physics experiments. High impulse currents are needed not only for tests on equipment such as lightning arresters and fuses but also for many other technical applications such as lasers, thermonuclear fusion, and plasma devices.
== Jedlik's tubular voltage generator ==
In 1863 Hungarian physicist [[Ányos Jedlik]] discovered the possibility of voltage multiplication and in 1868 demonstrated it with a "tubular voltage generator", which was successfully displayed at the [[Vienna World Exposition]] in 1873.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.hungarianquarterly.com/no162/020.html |title=Innovators and Innovations |last=Sipka |first=László |date=Summer 2001 |accessdate=August 23, 2010 |issue=162 |volume=XLII |journal=Hungarian Quarterly |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615095831/http://www.hungarianquarterly.com/no162/020.html |archivedate=June 15, 2011 |df= }}</ref> It was an early form of the impulse generators now applied in nuclear research.<ref>{{Cite book| edition = 2nd| publisher = Vista Books| isbn = 0962842206| last = Sisa| first = Stephen| title = The spirit of Hungary: a panorama of Hungarian history and culture| page = 308 | location = Morristown, N.J| date = 1990}}</ref>
The jury of the World Exhibition of 1873 in Vienna awarded his voltage multiplying condenser of [[Cascade connection (capacitors)|cascade connection]] with prize "For Development". Through this condenser, Jedlik framed the principle of surge generator of cascaded connection. (The Cascade connection was another important invention of Ányos Jedlik.)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.institutoideal.org/conteudo_eng.php?&sys=biblioteca_eng&arquivo=1&artigo=94&ano=2008 |title=Instituto IDEAL [English] |publisher=Instituto IDEAL [English] |date= |accessdate=2012-09-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322223457/http://www.institutoideal.org/conteudo_eng.php?&sys=biblioteca_eng&arquivo=1&artigo=94&ano=2008 |archivedate=2012-03-22 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hellotrade.com/energosolar/electronic-engineering.html |title=Electronic Engineering Manufacturer & Wholesale Supplier From Hungary - Energosolar |publisher=Hellotrade.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-10}}</ref>
== Marx generator == One form is the [[Marx generator]], after E. Marx who first proposed it in 1923. This consists of multiple capacitors that are first charged in parallel through charging resistors by a high-voltage, direct-current source and then connected in series and discharged through a test object by a simultaneous spark-over of the spark gaps. The impulse current generator comprises many capacitors that are also charged in parallel by a high-voltage, low-current, direct-current source, but it is discharged in parallel through resistances, inductances, and a test object by a spark gap.
== See also == * [[Fuse (electricity)]] * [[Laser]] * [[Nuclear fusion]] * [[Particle accelerator]] * [[Plasma (physics)]]
==References== * [http://www.himalayal.com/upfile/High_Voltage_Testing_Research_PDF/How_to_Commissioning_of_3600kV_Impulse_Voltage_Generator_Test_System.pdf How to Commissioning a Impulse Voltage Generator Test System] {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Electronic engineering]] [[Category:Hungarian inventions]]

{{Infobox person | image = Ugandan Minister for Energy and Minerals (10928382334).jpg | image_size = 150px | name = Irene Muloni | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = {{Birth date and age|1960|11|18|df=yes}} | alma_mater = '''[[Makerere University]]'''
{{small|([[Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering]])}}
'''[[Capella University]]'''
{{small|([[Master of Business Administration]])}} | occupation = [[Engineer|Electrical Engineer]] & [[Politician]] | years_active = 1986 — present | nationality = [[Uganda]]n | citizenship = [[Uganda]] | residence = [[Kampala]], [[Uganda]] | known_for = [[Politics]] | networth = | home_town = [[Bulambuli]] | title = Minister for Energy & Minerals }} '''Irene Nafuna Muloni''' is a [[Uganda]]n [[engineer|electrical engineer]], [[businesswoman]] and [[politician]]. She is the [[Energy|Cabinet Minister for Energy and Minerals]] in the [[Cabinet of Uganda|Ugandan Cabinet]]. She was first appointed to that position on 27 May 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/-/688334/1170806/-/c0y8sbz/-/index.html|title=Full of List of Ugandan Ministers Appointed by President Museveni |accessdate=14 June 2016 |date=28 May 2011 |newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]]| location=Kampala |author=Monitor Team}} In the new cabinet list released after the 2016 national elections, she maintained her position.{{cite web| format=PDF|title=Museveni’s new cabinet list At 6 June 2016| url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/blob/view/-/3235304/data/1345443/-/3o16hn/-/Museveni%2527s+cabinet.pdf|accessdate=14 June 2016|newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]]| date=6 June 2016 | location=Kampala|author=Uganda State House}} She served as the elected [[Parliament of Uganda|Member of Parliament]] for [[Bulambuli District|Bulambuli District Women's Representative]], from 2011 until 2016. In 2016, she lost her seat to Sarah Nambozo Wekomba, an Independent.{{cite web|url=http://ugandaradionetwork.com/story/minister-muloni-loses-bulambuli-seat|title=Minister Muloni Loses Bulambuli Seat | first=Denis |last=Olaka |date=19 February 2016 |publisher=[[Uganda Radio Network]] |location=Kampala |accessdate=14 June 2015}} ==Background and education== She was born on 18 November 1960, in what is known today, as [[Bulambuli District]].She attended ''Budadiri Girls' Primary School'' before entering [[Gayaza High School]].{{cite web|accessdate=14 June 2016|url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1008952/muloni-budadiri-village-girl-minister||title=Muloni: From A Budadiri Village Girl to A Minister |newspaper=[[New Vision]] |date=1 July 2011|location=Kampala| first=Vicky|last=Wandawa}} In 1982, she entered [[Makerere University]], the oldest university in [[East Africa]], to study Engineering. In 1986, she graduated with an honours [[Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering]] (BSc.E.Eng) degree. Later, she graduated with the degree of [[Master of Business Administration]] (MBA), from [[Capella University]] in [[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]], United States. She is also a Certified Public-Private Partnership Specialist, accredited by The Institute for Public-Private Partnerships, Inc. (IP3) and the Water, Engineering and Development Centre (WEDC) of [[Loughborough University]]. ==Work== From 2002 until 2011, Irene Muloni worked as the [[Managing Director]] of the Uganda Electricity Distribution Company Limited (UEDCL), a [[Uganda]]n parastatal company, responsible for distribution of electrical power to both commercial and retail customers nationwide. In 2011, she entered elective politics, by successfully contesting for the [[Bulambuli District|Bulambuli District Women's Representative]] in the [[Parliament of Uganda|9th Ugandan Parliament (2011 - 2016)]].{{cite web|newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]]| url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/blob/view/-/1163512/data/261485/-/whfr4wz/-/parliament.pdf|title=Members-Elect of The 9th Ugandan Parliament|date=March 2011| accessdate=19 May 2014|location=Kampala|author=Monitor Team|format=PDF}} On 27 May 2011, she was appointed [[Cabinet of Uganda|Minister of Energy & Minerals]], by [[Yoweri Museveni|President Yoweri Museveni]]. She replaced [[Hilary Onek]], who was appointed [[Minister of Internal Affairs]]. In the cabinet changes made on 6 June 2016, she maintained her cabinet appointment.{{cite web|accessdate=14 June 2016 | url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/314964607/New-Cabinet |title=Uganda's New Cabinet As At 6 June 2016 |date=6 June 2016 | publisher=Scribd.com |author=Uganda State House}} ==See also== *[[Cabinet of Uganda]] *[[Parliament of Uganda]] *[[Bulambuli District]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/-/688334/1170806/-/c0y8sbz/-/index.html Full of List of Ugandan Cabinet Ministers May 2011] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Muloni, Irene}} [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Government ministers of Uganda]] [[Category:Members of the Parliament of Uganda]] [[Category:Ugandan engineers]] [[Category:Ugandan women engineers]] [[Category:Ugandan electrical engineers]] [[Category:People from Bulambuli District]] [[Category:Women in technology]] [[Category:Makerere University alumni]] [[Category:Capella University alumni]] [[Category:Women government ministers of Uganda]] [[Category:Women members of the Parliament of Uganda]] [[Category:21st-century women engineers]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox officeholder |honorific-prefix = [[Her Excellency]] [[the Right Honourable]] |name = Julie Payette |honorific-suffix = {{post-nominals|country=CAN|CC|CMM|COM|CQ|CD|size=100%}} |image = Julie Payette in Ukraine - 2018 - (1516277015) (cropped).jpg |alt = Julie Payette in Ukraine in 2018 |office = 29th [[Governor General of Canada]] |monarch = [[Elizabeth II]] |primeminister = [[Justin Trudeau]] |term_start = October 2, 2017 |term_end = |predecessor = [[David Johnston]] |successor = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1963|10|20}} |birth_place = [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Canada |death_date = |death_place = |spouse = François Brissette ([[Divorce|div.]] 1999)
William Flynn (div. 2015) |children = 1 son (aged {{Age|2003|06|21}}){{cite news |last1=Rakobowchuk |first1=Peter |title=Astronaut's family has nerves of steel |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/astronauts-family-has-nerves-of-steel/article4212186/ |accessdate=December 30, 2017 |work=The Globe and Mail |date=June 13, 2009}} |residence = [[Rideau Hall]] |education = [[McGill University]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Engineering|BEng]])}}
[[University of Toronto]] {{small|([[Master of Applied Science|MASc]])}} |module = {{Infobox astronaut |child = yes |type = [[Canadian Space Agency|CSA]] astronaut |selection = [[List of astronauts by selection#1992|1992 CSA Group]] |time = 25 days 11 h 57 min |mission = [[STS-96]], [[STS-127]] |insignia = [[File:Sts-96-patch.svg|30px]] [[File:STS-127 patch.png|30px]]}} }} '''Julie Payette''' {{post-nominals|country=CAN|CC|CMM|COM|CQ|CD}} (born October 20, 1963) is the current [[Governor General of Canada]], the [[List of Governors General of Canada|29th]] since [[Canadian Confederation]].{{cite web| url=https://www.gg.ca/document.aspx?id=16943&lan=eng| title=Governor General: Ms. Julie Payette, Governor General| website=gg.ca| publisher=[[Governor General of Canada]]| date=July 13, 2017}}{{cite web | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/governor-general-canada-julie-payette-1.4201614 | publisher = [[CBC News]] | title=Former astronaut Julie Payette to be Canada's next governor general|date=July 12, 2017| archivedate = July 12, 2017| deadurl=No |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170712215210/http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/governor-general-canada-julie-payette-1.4201614}}{{cite news|last1=Scotti|first1=Monique|title=Julie Payette: Meet Canada's next governor general| url=http://globalnews.ca/news/3595524/julie-payette-meet-canadas-new-governor-general/|accessdate=July 13, 2017|work=Global News|date=July 13, 2017}} Before assuming office, she was a businesswoman, former member of the [[Canadian Astronaut Corps]], and engineer. Payette has completed two spaceflights, [[STS-96]] and [[STS-127]], logging more than 25 days in space. She served as chief astronaut for the [[Canadian Space Agency]] (CSA), and has served as [[Flight controller#Capsule Communicator (CAPCOM)|capsule communicator]] at NASA Mission Control Center in Houston. In July 2013, Payette was named chief operating officer for the [[Montreal Science Centre]], and in April 2014, she was appointed to the board of directors of the [[National Bank of Canada]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/partners/advappointmentnotices/julie-payette/article18799222 |newspaper=The Globe and Mail |title=Appointment Notice Julie Payette |author=National Bank of Canada |date=May 23, 2014}} On July 13, 2017, Prime Minister [[Justin Trudeau]] announced that [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] had approved the appointment of Payette as the next Governor General of Canada.{{cite web| url=http://pm.gc.ca/eng/news/2017/07/13/prime-minister-trudeau-announces-queens-approval-canadas-next-governor-general| title=Prime Minister Trudeau announces The Queen's approval of Canada's next Governor General| website=pm.gc.ca| publisher=[[Government of Canada]]| date=July 13, 2017}} She was sworn in on October 2, 2017.{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2017/10/02/julie-payette-to-be-installed-as-canadas-29th-governor-general.html|title=Julie Payette becomes Canada's 29th Governor General|first=Tonda|last=MacCharles|date=October 2, 2017|accessdate=October 2, 2017|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]}} As Governor General, Payette is entitled to be styled [[Excellency|Her Excellency]] while in office and [[The Right Honourable]] for life. ==Education and early career== Payette was born on October 20, 1963, in [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]],{{cite web| url=http://www.asc-csa.gc.ca/eng/astronauts/biopayette.asp| title=Biography of Julie Payette| date=September 10, 2013| publisher=[[Canadian Space Agency]]}} and lived in the [[Ahuntsic]] neighbourhood, attending Collège Mont-Saint-Louis and [[Collège Regina Assumpta]].{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/julie-payette-montreal-friends-remember-1.4202846 |title=Determination, generosity and spaghetti sauce: Meet Canada's new GG |publisher=CBC News |date=July 14, 2017}}{{cite web| url=https://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/women/030001-1412-e.html| title=Julie Payette – Celebrating Women's Achievements| website=collectionscanada.gc.ca| publisher=[[Library and Archives Canada]]| accessdate=July 13, 2017}} In 1982 she completed an [[International Baccalaureate]] diploma at the [[Atlantic College|United World College of the Atlantic]] in [[South Wales]], United Kingdom.{{cite book|author=Sonia Gueldenpfennig|title=Women in Space Who Changed the World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H6nmr5Kr0zQC&pg=PA75|date=December 2011|publisher=The Rosen Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-4488-5998-6|page=75}} For her undergraduate studies, Payette enrolled in [[McGill University]] where she completed a [[Bachelor of Engineering]] degree in electrical engineering in 1986, after which she completed a [[Master of Applied Science]] degree in computer engineering at the University of Toronto in 1990. Her thesis focused on computational linguistics, a field of artificial intelligence.{{cite web |url=http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/payette.html |publisher=National Aeronautics and Space Administration |title=Julie Payette: Astronaut, Canadian Space Agency (Biographical data) |location=Houston, Texas |date=June 2012 | archivedate = February 18, 2017 | deadurl = No | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170218194708/https://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/payette.html }}{{cite news |last=Flavelle |first=Dana |date=February 1, 2009 |title=Blasting off into space with Massey mementoes |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/2009/02/01/blasting_off_into_space_with_massey_mementoes.html |newspaper=Toronto Star |access-date=July 13, 2017}} She is a member of the [[Ordre des ingénieurs du Québec]] During her schooling, between 1986 and 1988, Payette also worked as a [[engineering|systems engineer]] for [[IBM]] Canada's Science Engineering division. From 1988 to 1990, as a graduate student at the [[University of Toronto]], she was involved in a high-performance computer architecture project and worked as a teaching assistant. At the beginning of 1991, Payette joined the Communications and science department of the [[IBM Zurich Research Laboratory]] in Switzerland, for a one-year visiting scientist appointment. When she returned to Canada, in January 1992, she joined the Speech Research Group of Bell-Northern Research in Montreal where she was responsible for a project in telephone speech comprehension using computer [[Speech recognition|voice recognition]]. Payette was married twice, first to François Brissette in the 1990s,{{cite magazine |last=Branswell |first=Brenda |date=May 17, 1999 |title=Ambition accomplished: The multitalented Julie Payette joins the roll of Canadian space travellers |magazine=Maclean's |location=Toronto}} and secondly to William Flynn, with whom she had a son in 2003, and from whom she divorced in 2015.{{cite news|url=http://nationalpost.com/news/politics/julie-payette-drops-legal-battle-to-seal-public-records-of-her-divorce-proceedings|periodical=National Post|title=Julie Payette drops legal battle to seal public records of her divorce proceedings|date=August 21, 2017|accessdate=October 3, 2017}} She is fluent in French (her mother tongue) and English, and can converse in Spanish, German, Italian and Russian. She plays the piano and has sung with the [[Montreal Symphony Orchestra]], [[Tafelmusik Baroque Orchestra|Tafelmusik Chamber Choir]][https://toronto.citynews.ca/2017/10/02/former-astronaut-to-be-installed-today-as-canadas-29th-governor-general/ "Former astronaut Julie Payette sworn in as Canada's 29th Governor General"]. ''CityNews'', by Terry Pedwell, The Canadian Press. October 2, 2017 and several others. She practices running, skiing, racquet sports and scuba diving. ==Canadian Space Agency== [[File:Julie Payette portrait.jpg|thumb|Payette's official portrait from [[STS-96]].]] Payette was selected by the Canadian Space Agency (CSA) as one of four astronauts from a field of 5,330 applicants in June 1992. After undergoing basic training in Canada, she worked as a technical advisor for the [[Mobile Servicing System]], an advanced robotics system and Canada's contribution to the [[International Space Station]].{{cite web |url=http://www.asc-csa.gc.ca/eng/astronauts/biopayette.asp |publisher=Canadian Space Agency |title=Biography of Julie Payette |date=January 21, 2013| archivedate = July 12, 2017 | deadurl = No | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170712005737/http://asc-csa.gc.ca/eng/astronauts/biopayette.asp |location=Longueuil, Quebec}} In 1993, Payette established the Human-Computer Interaction Group at the Canadian Astronaut Program and served as a technical specialist on the [[NATO]] International Research Study Group on speech processing. In preparation for a space assignment, Payette obtained her commercial [[Aviator|pilot]] licence and logged 120 hours as a research operator on reduced gravity aircraft. In April 1996, Payette was certified as a one-atmosphere deep sea diving suit operator. Payette obtained her captaincy on the [[Canadair CL-41 Tutor|CT-114 Tutor]] military jet at [[CFB Moose Jaw]] in February 1996 and her military instrument rating in 1997. Payette has logged more than 1,300 hours of flight time, including 600 hours on high-performance jet aircraft. Payette reported to the [[Johnson Space Center]] in August 1996 to begin mission specialist training. After completing one year of training, she was assigned to work on the Mobile Servicing System.{{cite book |last=Ellis |first=Lee |date=2004 |title=Who's Who of NASA Astronauts |publisher=Americana Group Publishing |location=River Falls, Wisconsin |isbn=0966796144 |pages=146}} Payette completed the initial astronaut training in April 1998.{{cite book|last=Melady |first=John |date=2009 |title=Canadians in Space: The Forever Frontier |publisher=Dundurn Press |location=Toronto |isbn=978-1-55002-940-6 |pages=137}} ===Spaceflight experience=== [[File:STS-127 Julie Payette near a window in the Kibo lab.jpg|thumb|Payette aboard the [[Kibo (ISS module)|Kibo laboratory]] of the [[International Space Station]] during [[STS-127]].]] Payette served as chief astronaut for the Canadian Space Agency from 2000 to 2007. She also worked as [[capsule communicator]] at the Mission Control Center in Houston for several years, including the return to flight mission [[STS-114]]. She was lead capsule communicator during [[STS-121]]. ====STS-96==== Payette flew on the [[Space Shuttle Discovery|Space Shuttle ''Discovery'']] from May 27 to June 6, 1999, as part of the crew of [[STS-96]]. During the mission, the crew performed the first manual docking of the shuttle to the International Space Station, and delivered four tons of logistics and supplies to the station. On ''Discovery'', Payette served as a mission specialist. Her main responsibility was to operate the [[Canadarm]] robotic arm from the space station.{{cite web |url=http://www.inventivewomen.com/library/library_julie_payette_que.shtml |title=Inventive Women Biographies: Julie Payette | archivedate = February 17, 2009 | deadurl = Yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090217154337/http://www.inventivewomen.com/library/library_julie_payette_que.shtml }} The STS-96 mission was accomplished in 153 orbits of the Earth, traveling over {{convert|6000000|km|mi|spell=in}} in 9 days, 19 hours and 13 minutes. Payette became the first Canadian to participate in an ISS assembly mission and to board the Space Station. ====STS-127==== Payette visited the space station again in 2009 as a mission specialist aboard [[Space Shuttle Endeavour|Space Shuttle ''Endeavour'']] during mission [[STS-127]] from July 15 to 31, 2009, and was the flight engineer and lead robotic operator during the mission.{{Cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/home/hqnews/2008/feb/HQ_08052_Crew_Announcements.html |title=NASA Assigns Crews for STS-127 and Expedition 19 Missions |accessdate=February 11, 2008| publisher=NASA|year=2008| author=NASA | archivedate = June 8, 2017 | deadurl = No | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170608015738/https://www.nasa.gov/home/hqnews/2008/feb/HQ_08052_Crew_Announcements.html }} At that time, [[Robert Thirsk]] was a member of [[Expedition 20]] on the space station. ''Endeavour''{{'}}s docking at the space station marked the first time two Canadians met in space.{{cite book |last=Melady |first=John |date=2011 |title=Maple Leaf in Space: Canada's Astronauts |publisher=Dundurn Press |location=Toronto |isbn=978-1-55488-752-1 |pages=136}} During her second mission, Payette brought a signed sweater of the famed [[Montreal Canadiens]] player [[Maurice Richard]], stating she had brought Richard, who was known as "The Rocket", into the rocket to celebrate [[Montreal Canadiens centennial|the hockey team's 100th anniversary]].{{cite news |url=http://ottawa.ctvnews.ca/payette-to-carry-piece-of-ottawa-valley-legend-into-space-1.407589 |title=Payette to carry piece of Ottawa Valley legend into space |work=CTV News |date=June 13, 2009 |accessdate=July 13, 2017}} ==Post-CSA== [[File:Olympic flag carried into BC Place at 2010 Winter Olympics opening ceremony (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|Several notable Canadians, including Payette (right back), carrying the Olympic flag at the [[2010 Winter Olympics opening ceremony]] in Vancouver]] During 2010–2011, she worked at the [[Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars]] in Washington, D.C. and was also a scientific delegate to the United States for the Quebec Government.{{cite web |title=Featured Alumni |url=https://alumni.utoronto.ca/news-and-stories/featured-alumni/julie-payette |publisher=University of Toronto |date=November 28, 2013}} {{cite web |title=Former Public Policy Scholar Canada: Julie Payette |url=https://www.wilsoncenter.org/person/julie-payette |publisher=Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars |year=2011}} For the next three years, Payette was CEO of the [[Montreal Science Centre]] of the [[Old Port of Montreal|Société du Vieux-Port de Montréal]].{{cite news |url=http://montrealgazette.com/news/local-news/julie-payette-leaving-job-as-director-of-montreal-science-centre |title=Julie Payette leaving job as director of Montreal Science Centre |newspaper=The Gazette|location=Montreal |agency=The Canadian Press |date=October 13, 2016 |accessdate=July 14, 2017}} During that time, she was also a Vice President of the [[Canada Lands Company]].{{cite web |first=Katharine |last=Raymond |url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/julie-payette/ |title=Julie Payette |date=March 2, 2017 |publisher=Canadian Encyclopedia}}{{cite news |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2017/07/13/former-astronaut-julie-payette-will-be-canadas-next-governor-general.html |title=Former astronaut Julie Payette will be Canada's next Governor General |date=July 13, 2017 |newspaper=Toronto Star}} Payette has served on boards of directors, at Queen's University, Canada's Own the Podium Olympic program, Montréal Science Centre foundation, Robotique FIRST Québec, Drug Free Kids Canada, the Montreal Bach Festival, the National Bank of Canada, Développement Aéroport Saint-Hubert de Longueuil, and others. She was recently appointed to the [[International Olympic Committee]]'s Women in Sports Commission.{{cite news |url=http://globalnews.ca/news/3595524/julie-payette-meet-canadas-new-governor-general/ |title=Julie Payette: Meet Canada’s next governor general |last=Scotti |first=Monique |work=Global News |date=July 13, 2017 |accessdate=July 14, 2017}} She is a member of the Ordre des ingénieurs du Québec and a fellow of the International Academy of Astronautics. As well, Payette is a member of the Faculty of Engineering Advisory Board of McGill University.{{cite web |url=http://www.pm.gc.ca/eng/news/2017/07/13/biography-julie-payette-oc-cq |title=Biography of Julie Payette, OC, CQ |publisher=Justin Trudeau, Prime Minister of Canada |date=July 13, 2017}} ==Governor General== Payette was announced on July 13, 2017, as Prime Minister [[Justin Trudeau]]'s recommendation to be the [[List of Governors General of Canada|29th]] [[Governor General of Canada]]. Her term was scheduled to begin October 2, 2017, after the completion of briefings from the incumbent, [[David Johnston]].{{cite web|title=Julie Payette named Governor General|url=http://www.macleans.ca/news/julie-payette-named-governor-general/|website=Maclean's|accessdate=July 14, 2017}} Her salary was set at $290,660 per annum and an official residence at Rideau Hall.{{cite news|title=Former astronaut Julie Payette to be Canada's next governor general|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/governor-general-canada-julie-payette-1.4201614|date=July 12, 2017|website=CBC|accessdate=September 27, 2018}} After the announcement was made, Johnston issued a statement congratulating Payette and welcoming "a Canadian of extraordinary achievement, admired by all".{{cite web|title=Message Following the Announcement of Canada's 29th Governor General|url=https://www.gg.ca/document.aspx?id=16942&lan=eng|website=The Governor General of Canada|accessdate=July 14, 2017}} As the designate, Payette had her first official meeting with Queen [[Elizabeth II]] on September 20, 2017, at [[Balmoral Castle]] when she was also invested as an Extraordinary Companion of the Order of Canada (CC), an Extraordinary Commander of the Order of Military Merit (CMM) and a Commander of the Order of Merit of the Police Forces (COM) by Her Majesty.{{cite web|url=https://www.gg.ca/document.aspx?id=16999&lan=eng|title=The Governor General of Canada|first=The Office of the Secretary to the Governor|last=General|website=Gg.ca|accessdate=October 2, 2017}} Payette was installed as Canada's 29th Governor General on October 2, 2017. Afterwards, she urged Canadians to work together on issues such as climate change, migration and poverty. "Anyone can accomplish anything and rise to the challenge as long as they are willing to work with others, to let go of the personal agenda, to reach a higher goal and to do what is right for the common good. This is exactly what I hope my mandate as the Governor General will reflect," Payette said.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/payette-governor-general-investiture-1.4313299|title=Julie Payette pushes strength of team work, power of dreams in debut speech as GG|publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=October 2, 2017}} At the Canadian Science Policy Conference the next month, she argued strongly for greater public acceptance of science, saying that too many people believe in astrology, deny climate change, and believe that "maybe taking a sugar pill will cure cancer."{{cite news|title=Canadian Governor General's Defense of Science 'A Breath of Fresh Air'|last=Frazier|first=Kendrick|date=March–April 2018|work=Skeptical Inquirer|pages=12–13}} [[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry]] concerning climate change, commented that her remarks were "refreshing". George Dvorsky from Gizmodo.org stated '"Her words were a breath of fresh air"'.{{cite journal|title=Canadian Governor General's Defense of Science 'A Breath of Fresh Air'|journal=Skeptical Inquirer|date=2018|volume=42|issue=2|pages=12–13|publisher=Committee for Skeptical Inquiry}} ===Re-evaluating the role of GG=== As she was completing her first year as the viceregal representative in September 2018, Payette faced some criticism about controversial comments she had made against those who believe in creationism and those who did not believe in climate change. Maintaining her position on the issues, Payette emphasized the importance of debate and critical thinking but admitted that she was still growing into her role and needed more time to adapt to the position. "I learned that you have to be careful about how you say things, but not what you say," she added.{{cite web |date=August 30, 2018 |title=Gov. Gen. Julie Payette on what she learned from her controversial comments on science, religion and climate|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/governor-general-julie-payette-climate-speech-lessons-1.4805004 |work=CBC |access-date=September 24, 2018}} Some time later, she offered an additional explanation to CPAC. "I made a speech as I had as an astronaut and I'm not an astronaut any longer, I'm governor general. I represent all Canadians. I've learned those lessons."{{cite news |date=September 30, 2018 |title=It's not easy being GG; Payette tries to reassure staff as criticism mounts ceremony|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/payette-governor-general-anniversary-2018-1.4844727 |work=CBC |access-date=October 1, 2018}} Weeks later, she faced criticism about her work ethic, with some suggesting that she had not devoted enough time and dedication to the role of GG and had not visited several of the provinces in her nearly 12-month tenure. The ''[[Toronto Star]]'' published specifics confirming the more numerous appearances her two predecessors had made per year.{{cite news |date=September 21, 2018 |title=Gov. Gen. Julie Payette faces questions over her workload and schedule |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-governor-general-julie-payette-needs-to-make-a-choice-about-her-role/ |work=Globe and Mail |access-date=September 24, 2018}} Rideau Hall spokesperson Marie-Ève Létourneau said that "The first year of every mandate is a period of learning, adjustment and adaptation from both the Governor General and Rideau Hall staff."{{cite news |date=September 23, 2018 |title=Gov. Gen. Julie Payette faces questions over her workload and schedule |url=https://www.thestar.com/politics/federal/2018/09/23/gov-gen-julie-payette-faces-questions-over-her-workload-and-schedule.html |work=Toronto Star |access-date=September 24, 2018}} The ''[[Globe and Mail]]'' opinion piece offered this conclusion on Payette's tenure to date. "Canadians need to know that the Governor-General is fulfilling her duties. Her biggest challenge right now is to convince us that she is worthy of our trust". Later in September, the GG's office confirmed that Payette would not preside over the 2018 Governor General's History Awards ceremony.{{cite news |date=September 26, 2018 |title=Julie Payette doesn't plan to preside over 2018 Governor General's History Awards ceremony|url=https://nationalpost.com/news/politics/julie-payette-wont-preside-over-2018-governor-generals-history-awards-ceremony |work=National Post |access-date=September 27, 2018}} This may have been only one of several traditional roles that she would not fulfill; a full plan for her involvement in such discretionary responsibilities with various organizations was to be published but was not yet available at the time. On September 27, Payette acknowledged the articles that had painted an "unfavourable image of our work" in an e-mail to staff, expressed regret about the effect of the criticisms on morale, and assured them that she was "very proud of all we have achieved together to date". ==Titles, styles, honours, and arms== ===Titles=== {{Infobox viceroy styles | image = [[File:Crest of the Governor-General of Canada.svg|50px]] | name = Julie Payette | dipstyle = Her Excellency the Right Honourable
''Son Excellence la très honorable'' | offstyle = Your Excellency
''Votre Excellence'' }} * October 2, 2017 –: ''Her Excellency the Right Honourable'' Julie Payette, Governor General and Commander-in-Chief in and over Canada{{cite web|url=http://nationalpost.com/news/politics/what-does-the-governor-general-do-all-day-a-national-post-investigation|title=What does the governor general do all day? A National Post investigation|date=October 2, 2017|website=National Post|accessdate=October 2, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pm.gc.ca/eng/news/2017/10/02/statement-prime-minister-welcome-canadas-new-governor-general-right-honourable-julie|title=Statement by the Prime Minister to welcome Canada's new Governor General, the Right Honourable Julie Payette|date=October 2, 2017|website=Om.gc.ca|accessdate=October 2, 2017}} ===Honours===

{{unsourced|date=December 2014}}
This is a list of [[Architectural lighting design|Lighting Design]] software for use in analyzing [[photometrics]], [[Building Information Modeling|BIM]] (Building Information Modeling), and [[3D modeling]]. The software is typically used by importing the structural design via [[Computer-aided design|CAD]] files. Then lighting elements are inserted. And finally, the lighting objects are associated with a photometry via IES files. The photometry of a light fixture describes the way it distributes its light into space. Once this process is completed, the [[illuminance]] and [[luminance]] produced by each fixture in the space can be calculated. The output is typically a diagram indicating these by means of colors or numbers. This typically is the goal of technical photometry software.
In marketing and higher-level design, 3D photometric analysis is useful to give a graphical (no numerics) output of a proposed design.
;Open source * [[Radiance (software)|Radiance]]
;Proprietary * [https://cast-soft.com/wysiwyg-lighting-design/ Wysiwyg] (CAST software) * [[AGi32]] * RELUX * DIALux * DL-Light * [[FocusTrack]] * [[TracePro]]
[[Category:Lighting]] [[Category:Computer-aided design software]] [[Category:Architectural lighting design]]

page.title: List of video games derived from mods

revision.text:
This is a list of standalone [[video game]]s that have been ported from a [[Mod (video gaming)|modification]] of another video game, and/or that are entirely based on a modification of another video game. A game is considered standalone when it does not require the purchase or installation of any other game (including separate [[Game engine|engine software]] such as the [[Source SDK]]) in order to run. ==List== {{Inc-vg|date=March 2016}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ |- ! data-sort-type="text" | Game ! data-sort-type="text" | Original dependency ! class="unsortable" | Mod release ! class="unsortable" | Standalone release ! class="unsortable" | Additional information |- | ''[[Alien Swarm]]'' | ''[[Unreal Tournament 2004]]'' | 28 May 2004 | 19 July 2010{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/630/ |title=Alien Swarm |accessdate=12 March 2016 |work=[[Steam (software)|Steam]] |publisher=[[Valve Corporation]]}} | The standalone version was developed by [[Valve Corporation]] and ported to the [[Source (game engine)|Source engine]]. |- | ''[[Angels Fall First: Planetstorm]]'' | ''[[Unreal Tournament 3]]'' | 20 October 2008{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/mods/angels-fall-first-planetstorm/news/angels-fall-first-planetstorm-v100-released |title=Angels Fall First: Planetstorm V1.00 Released! |accessdate=12 March 2016}} | 1 October 2015{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/367270/ |title=Angels Fall First |accessdate=12 March 2016}} | |- | ''[[Antichamber]]'' | ''[[Unreal Tournament 3]]'' | 2009 | 31 January 2013{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/219890/ |title=Antichamber |accessdate=12 March 2016}} | The mod was originally known as ''Hazard: The Journey of Life''.{{cite web |url=https://www.engadget.com/2011/07/06/indie-game-hazard-the-journey-of-life-is-now-antichamber/ |title=Indie game 'Hazard: The Journey of Life' is now Antichamber |date=7 June 2011 |author=JC Fletcher |publisher=[[Engadget]] |accessdate=12 March 2016}} |- | ''[[The Ball (video game)|The Ball]]'' | ''[[Unreal Tournament 3]]'' | 2008 | 26 October 2010{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/games/the-ball/news/release35 |title=The Ball Released! |accessdate=13 March 2016}} | |- | ''[[Black Mesa (video game)|Black Mesa]]'' | ''[[Half-Life 2]]'' | 14 September 2012 | 5 May 2015{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/362890/ |title=Black Mesa |accessdate=12 March 2016}} | The game is the remake of [[Valve Corporation]]'s game [[Half-Life (video game)|Half-Life]]. |- | ''[[Chivalry: Medieval Warfare]]'' | ''[[Half-Life 2]]'' | 10 September 2011 | 16 October 2012{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/219640/ |title=Chivalry: Medieval Warfare |accessdate=12 March 2016}} | The original mod was called ''[[Age of Chivalry]]''. The standalone version did not use the [[Source Engine]] like ''Half-Life 2''. Instead, it was developed for [[Unreal Engine 3]].{{cite web |url=http://www.gamesetwatch.com/2011/03/chivalry_firstperson_online_me.php |title=Chivalry: First-Person Online Medieval Combat |date=18 March 2011 |author=Eric Caoili |publisher=[[GameSetWatch]] |accessdate=12 March 2016}} |- | ''[[Counter-Strike (video game)|Counter-Strike]]'' | ''[[Half-Life (video game)|Half-Life]]'' | 19 June 1999 | 8 November 2000 | The game received [[Counter-Strike|multiple sequels]] and a [[Source Engine]] remake named ''[[Counter-Strike: Source]]''. |- | ''[[Cry of Fear]]'' | ''[[Half-Life (video game)|Half-Life]]'' | 22 February 2012{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/games/cry-of-fear/news/cry-of-fear-released |title=Cry of Fear - Released! |accessdate=12 March 2016}} | 25 April 2013{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/news/10472/ |title=Now Available - Cry of Fear |accessdate=12 March 2016}} | |- | ''[[D-Day: Normandy]]'' | ''[[Quake II]]'' | 2000{{cite web |url=http://www.ddaydev.com/site/docs.php?go=aboutdday |title=Welcome to D-Day: Normandy! |accessdate=14 March 2016}} | 2002 | |- | ''[[The Dark Mod]]'' | ''[[Doom III]]'' | 17 October 2009{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/mods/the-dark-mod/news/its-here2 |title=Its Here! |accessdate=13 March 2016}} | 14 April 2013{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/mods/the-dark-mod/news/the-dark-mod-20-standalone |title=The Dark Mod 2.0 Standalone!
